pros: Best working atmosphere and nice colleagues
cons: None I can think of or mention

job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good health care at low price
cons: Work expectations are unreasonable and unrealistic

job_title: Researcher V in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Good benefits, work-life balance easy commute
cons: A lot of problems in the administration

pros: short commute, friendly environment, variety of patients
cons: busy call, research, turnover, stability

pros: friendly environment, interesting career development opportunities
cons: slow paced, several departments have antiquated approaches

pros: Lot of freedom to do innovative research
cons: Lack of career development plans

pros:
Working outside
Flexible hours
Several locations on campus
cons: Student work ethic can be poor

pros: Its a really nice university.
cons: No cons that I can think of.

review_title: A public University dedicated to research, education and service.
pros: The University of Minnesota prides itself in being a great research institution dedicated to excellence, equity and opportunity. The hours are more than reasonable (8 hours each day is expected for full time staff) and flexibility of hours is pretty grand (depending on your department). The benefits package is one of the best I have seen making the University of Minnesota a wonderful place to work. The culture is typically more casual and laid back making it comfortable for most people. Almost every employee values education and research and are happy to be supporting a public institution excelling in these areas.
cons: Pay is not the greatest and it is very difficult to get a raise or pay increase. One of the only ways for this to happen is to get another job offer and hope they match it, someone leaves or someone retires. Being a public institution everyone's pay is public knowledge creating another potential for employee dissatisfaction. It takes time to get training (and there is quite a bit of it) for access to different systems and there are many times people are unclear of the process to follow to obtain access to do their job. Once you have the key contacts you are good to go though. There is just a bit of digging at first.

pros: It is a great research University
cons: too cold in the winter

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: great coworkers and management. flexible with schedule
cons: lax nature in work place

pros:
1) Friendly environment, positive interactions with coworkers and managers,

2) My supervisor encourages taking advantage of the learning / seminars / professional development offerings here, which is good if you have a curious personality. The university encourages learning as well, although you’ll need to find a supervisor that agrees with it

3) Benefits are good - depending on your position, you can either be P&A (401k match) or Civil Service (Minnesota’s state pension program instead of 401k match)

Overall, the learning culture and supportive environment is what has kept me here thus far.
cons:
1) UMN culture is still a bit slow. The processes and workflows in place can take a long time to change, especially compared to industry

2) Your experience with the UMN will HIGHLY depend on the team you’re on.  Managers especially all tend to do things in different ways, and some are just better at it than others

3) Pay and upward mobility (in context of salary increases) is hard to get compared to industry standard. Make sure you negotiate well on the first offer

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: opportunity, cost, community, activities, resources
cons: Big, crime, not much else.

review_title: Love the academic environment, flexibility, and benefits, but not the ambiguity and lack of communication at times
pros:
Benefits are awesome!  Benefits for staff in a Professional & Administrative (P&A) position which is considered an annually renewable contract position are equivalent to faculty benefits (e.g., long-term disability, significant contributions to retirement, vacation, sick leave).  While the benefits are better for P&A positions compared to regular staff positions (e.g., Civil Service), they can be less secure in that it is easier for P&A contract positions to not be renewed than to lay off Union staff with continuing positions. 

Potential option to participate in Regents Scholarship program which significantly pays for course credits taken at the U of M.

Ongoing opportunities for training and access to valuable resources at the U of M

May have more autonomy and flexibility

Potential opportunities to move into different positions within the institution if desired
cons:
Depending on the position, who you report to etc.,
- compensation may be lower (but benefits and potential life balance may offset this)
- lack of funding to cover position is possible
- may be ambiguity in terms of roles and responsibilities
- may not receive sufficient time to meet with or get feedback from boss
- may be some work place politics going on

review_title: For IT professionals, University salaries are low while other benefits are waning
job_title: Info Tech Professional in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good work-life balance. Attempts are being made to improve the technical tracks apart from management, so better and more meaningful job titles, also a move to Professional & Administrative (P&A) job classifications, which is considered a step better than Civil Service.
cons: Bureaucracy, low salaries (even for IT professionals). Regarding the technical vs management tracks, there is little chance for effective benefit since the only way to "move up" in terms of salary remains the management track. Moving to P&A job classifications reduces job stability (it is harder to get rid of Civil Service employees) in the context of ever-shrinking budget dollars.

review_title: Not too bad for continuing education
job_title: End User Support in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The University has a regent scholarship program that pays employee one hundred (100%) tuition for the first bachelor degree and pays seventy five(75%) tuition for the next one. It has great benefits (health and time off) for the employee and the spouse and children as well. The longer you work the more hours you get for time off. People stays here for a while because of that. Depending on your supervisors, you can have a pretty flexible work hours as well. You are surrounded by lots of smart people that you can learn and ask questions. The people I work with, I consider them family and they treat me as such.
cons: The promotions tends to be difficult considering there are many people worked longer than you. You will need to move to different colleges or departments to be promoted. It can be slow pace sometimes, unless you are willing to work on projects that will certainly take a lot of your time but no pay raise. Your salary is pretty much depended on the the number of students enrolled in your college and sometimes it can be frozen (no pay raise) if the college budget is not healthy.

pros: Really meaningful work, great experience builder, awesome coworkers.  This was my second job out of college and it was the best.  Funding issues caused the position to close, but my superiors worked very hard to get funding, it just didn't happen.
cons: A couple, but very tolerable. Every job has cons, but the pros for me outweighed the cons so much that these are hardly relevant. I worked a lot with student workers which is great except their turnover rate is naturally high (duh).  So sometimes we get great students helping and sometimes we are stuck with some that are ... well less apt to the job.  Secondly, just by the nature of our work, our hours were very rigid. Unless you had specifically taken time off, there is no way you are not going to be working during the normal lab hours.  Which, like I said, is just part of this specific job. It does make personal errands like post office, bank, etc, difficult during the day.

review_title: I hope you don't expect respect.
pros: This is an easy college job if you are lifeguard certified. There are rarely saves (2/year). You don't have to really talk to other people much. There are not a ton of rules to memorize and most patrons already know the rules so there isn't much enforcement needing to be done.
cons: The management team is horrible. The head guards don't talk to each other. One will tell you one thing, another will tell you another. They have no idea what is going on. The manager is even worse. There are job requirements that they are not open about until you are already in the position. It was money, but I wanted to quit every day.

review_title: Intellectually stimulating but somewhat disorganized and dysfunctional.
pros: Great opportunities to take in seminars and conferences and to interact with researchers.  Able to work very independently.
cons: Organizational structure can be very dysfunctional.  Not centrally managed - seems like many small units functioning on their own, sometimes interacting with each other but at other times colliding.  It takes a long time to learn the various technological systems necessary to get work done, and it takes quite a while to build a support network because of the huge size of the University.  I had very little training after I was hired, so I had to learn by the "sink or swim" method.  I have worked here for over 5 years and have never had a performance review!

review_title: To be a Graduate Instructor is a Great Way to Be Young and Poor
pros: I got to design and teach my own courses. I worked with over 200 UMN undergrads, both at the Minneapolis campus and up in Duluth. UMN has *really* great support staff -- the Writing Center, the Center for Teaching and Learning, the Office of Diversity. Health insurance and health care at UMN was always of superior quality and great value.
cons: My department was not always well-managed -- different components of the work have to come together, and didn't always during the time I was working there. My academic advisors don't seem to have prepared me well for the working world. My program was too easy, and I don't feel as rigorous or creative as my peers in the professional world -- but I mainly blame myself for this.

review_title: One rating does not say it all.  The "U" is highly regionalized with some areas being run well and others very poorly.
job_title: Student Personnel Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Flexible, great sick day benefits, closed most national holidays, pride of working for the public good, being surrounded by great "thinkers", being surrounded by great students.
cons: Very poorly managed in many areas, performance management system is almost nonexistent,  employee development opportunities are poor for an institution focused on education, many leaders are former academics not professional managers, culture encourages status quo not innovation.  To sum it up, on my last performance evaluation my manager said "we think you're doing good because no students have complained".

pros: MN is beautiful.  And if you are an undergrad, it's relatively cheap
cons: The administration is pretty far out-of-touch.  These guys seem to chronically disengage with faculty, and it leads to a lot of raw feelings.  Most of the great professors are here because they love MN-have cabins, have kids, etc.  There is a reason for this: the U of M does very little to maintain mid-level faculty.  This is obviously a huge problem that most of their departments are paying for through the nose.  It's a tough place to be.

review_title: Great place to grow in your career.
pros: Great benefits. Many opportunities to advance in your career by taking advantage of discounted classes, professional networking groups on campus, and being a part of the culture. Once you're in it's fairly easy to get interviews for different or more challenging roles in other departments.
cons: Your coworkers can build you up or tear you down. Some work groups have a terrible culture and others can be really great and supportive. It can be difficult to feel connected to the values of the UMN brand when you're working in a department that holds you back or doesn't value innovation.

review_title: Not a bad place for engineering graduate student
pros: I'm a PhD candidate in an engineering department, working as both a research and teaching assistant. The U has a decent pay for graduate assistants. The health insurance is great! I have never heard a single complaint about the health insurance provided for the graduate assistants. The school is in a pretty nice location, and commuting is very convenient. The stipend is good, if not the best among major engineering schools. The school has almost every single field (engineering, computer science, med school, agriculture...), so interdisciplinary research is very common.
cons: This is probably common for most public schools: lack of funding. Over the past few years, a lot of PhD students had to work as a TA (including me!) to make up for the full 50% assistantship. Many equipment in our department need replacement. A lot of paperwork if you ever want to do something, even though I do see changes occur.

review_title: Good but Could be Much Better
pros: Excellent benefits, good resources available to staff, large tuition discount, good work life balance.
cons:
The U is a faculty led organization.  This isn't bad in itself but little attention is paid to selecting and then training the correct faculty to be leaders.   Being an expert in something does not correlate with being a good leader.  

Organizational structure is very decentralized.  This makes organization effectiveness and strategic alignment initiatives hit or miss.  Administrative functions report to the business unit which means that their effectiveness is hit or miss.  Overall, lots of silos with Chiefs who don't want to give up control.

Many of these things are probably common in universities...but we can and should do better.

review_title: Good opportunity cut short by insufficient grant funding
job_title: Junior Lab Technician in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
-Great benefits: in addition to the standard medical and dental, I enjoyed having discounted bus fare
-Offers great opportunity to contribute to meaningful research
-Top of the line equipment in many research labs
cons:
-Limited interaction with coworkers/supervisors (though this is probably the case in most academic labs)
-Limited job security: if your department can't secure grant funding, they may have no choice but to send you out the door
-Poor work life balance: I always exceeded 40 hours per week, and my social life suffered as a result
-Highly stressful at times, in part due to the nature of the scientific research, but also due to the professor's extremely high expectations

job_title: Veterinary Technician in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Great learning environment and opportunity to advance your skills. 
Was given the opportunity to transfer departments after a couple years to focus on something new. 
If you can invest the time (on-call and holiday shifts) you can learn a lot. Great place to pursue your VTS.
Worked with some very good people. (Techs, Doctors and support staff)
Good pay and benefits for the profession. 
Accumulate good amount of sick and vacation time.
cons:
There were times of high turnaround.  Being short staffed made it difficult to get time off. 
Certain departments do not have as many job opportunities.
Less work/life balance working in 24/7 departments.
Have to pay for parking on campus. Parking and transportation services can be difficult and rude.
Occasional problems with payroll, inaccuracies on my paycheck during a time of restructuring pay periods. Payroll in my building was very nice and tried to be helpful but it was above her. Payroll at central was very difficult to communicate with.

review_title: Staff Accounting for U of MN Cancer Center
pros: This is a large organization with literally dozens of resources in their HR department for training, development, symposiums, etc. The atmosphere of my office was that as long as you completed your tasks, you could be more laid back, socialize, etc. But when there were deadlines (i.e. the end of the fiscal year rush in June) everyone was expected to put in the hours.
cons: Its strength is its weakness-the university is so large, it is difficult to navigate all its resources. Communication between departments (between our department and those we budget or account for) is awful. Additionally, a recent (2 years ago) switch in enterprise systems has been a rocky transition.

review_title: Moving in the right direction, but a culture that is risk-averse and slow to change.
pros: Lots of smart people. Supportive management. Good benefits. Opportunities to pursue personal projects as long as you can articulate the potential benefits, owing to the University's stated commitment to innovation -- although when it comes to implementation you might have a harder sell on your hands.
cons: To say that this place is slow to change is an understatement. It's a part of the culture, for better or worse. Information systems are clunky and difficult to use. Processes that don't make any sense in today's environment continue because "that's how we've always done it." Different departments often times take a confrontational attitude with each other rather than working cooperatively.

job_title: Executive Office and Administrative Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Really good benefits. Tuition benefit. There are several opportunities to move around to different jobs. The job is broad so you develop a range of skills. There are a lot of great things about working here. It is a good atmosphere and good place for networking.
cons: The tuition benefit is 75%, so you still have to pay 25%. If you're like me and already have student loans, it's very difficult to come up with the rest of the 25%. especially since you will have the tax on the 75% that is covered com out of your paycheck.  The pay is decent, but you can make more at other places with a more focused job. The union is great for representation, but also is very limiting.  you are stuck in a wage contract, so your raises are not merit based, nor can you ask for a raise if you are doing more work. The raises in the union are below cost of living.

review_title: Once a great place to work, but budget cuts and poor management threaten the future of the institution
pros:
Professional development - most managers are willing to help employees to learn new skills and will pay for training.
Work/life balance - better than corporate, no matter the complaints.
Opportunities - it's a big place, so moving around is easier than in smaller companies (especially at lower levels)
Benefits - used to be very, very good, but now getting cut every year
cons:
Pay - lower than what you would find outside. My salary is about 70% of the equivalent salary in the corporate world
Politics - people let politics get in the way of logical decisions, which eventually could doom the institution
Management - run by academics, not business people. This has some positives during good times, but is downright scary during the bad times; plus, making faculty do anything is next to impossible.

pros: Intellegent professors, relaxed schedule (mostly), very nice office, relatively interesting work with some flexibility
cons:
Meager pay for the degree level and technical ability, project is determined solely based on research professor's grant funding which may not be aligned with own technical interests. Personally, the experience did not enhance my technical ability and ultimately served to bide time while looking for the next job. Job security non-existent since it is based on the funding timeline of the grant.

The post-doctoral experience, in general, has become a mode of treading water and biding time in between graduate school and career. This is in contrast to previous eras when a post-doc position was meant as an apprenticeship for the academic improvement of an individual who had career plans to become a professor.

job_title: Student Maintenance Worker in Minneapolis, MN
pros: There are some great people, flexible hours, and work well scheduling around students class schedules. Pretty good pay for a student job too, and the work was enjoyable. As much as i complain about a few of the bad apples, there are a lot of great people, and I met several who I will stay in touch with for the rest of my life.
cons: Several of the full-time employees are very lazy and make the students pick up the slack. The supervisors are afraid to come down on anyone for fear that the union will defend them and file grievances, which is a terrible way to manage. Also, a lot of the full-time employees dislike their jobs, and are rude and bitter towards the students, some what out of jealousy.

review_title: Review from and Admin: Great benefits and resources, but not a lot of opportunity to move up.
pros:
- The benefits are pretty decent
- There are a ton of resources on camps, from places to eat to a post office to clinics and a movie theater
- The location is great- along the Mississippi- so you're never very far from nature
- Job security- once you're in, you could stay in that role for a long time
- If you're full time, you can get 75% of tuition off. That is something I'm going to be sad not to take advantage of if/ when I leave!
cons:
- It's really difficult to move up in any meaningful way. "Promotions" tend to be lateral.
- We just went through a wage freeze, so pay is not awesome.

review_title: Overall great employer, easy to work with, decent pay, reasonable expectations.
pros: I enjoyed the small class size when teaching at the University of Minnesota Crookston. It made it easy to bond with the students. They put a high priority on employee satisfaction. The pay is fair and the benefits and time off are also good. There are many opportunities for professional growth, and financial support for employees to seek it.
cons: My direct supervisor was not assertive enough to keep the department under control. There was a lot of high-school type behavior among some of the instructors which affected relationships throughout the department. Many times I felt as though some appropriately placed disciplinary actions would solve several issues.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Falcon Heights, Ramsey, MN
pros:
Very nice place to work, surrounded by really nice people and professionals. Awesome place to do good research, depending on your field. Masterclass healthcare facility and healthcare plan offered by the university. 
Costly, yet affordable living facilities on or close to campus, especially if you have kids.
cons: Postdocs have access to only Optional Retirement Programs, no matter how many years of experience you have acquired. Explicitly, University does not offer retirement plans for postdocs wherein matching contributions are made.

pros: It's a comfortable, relaxed environment. It's easy to get a good job as a student here. The hours are simple, the staff are friendly, helpful, and hard-working. Most of the time you never see or get involved with higher management, and that means freedom from micromanagement. People like their jobs, and they stick around for a while, even as student workers.
cons: The University doesn't treat some of its staff very well. On the one hand, the workers are state employees, so they receive good benefits and competitive wages, but two different major unions have gone on strike in the last three years over wage increases, which is not a good thing. Overall, I feel like management is paid far too much for a public organization. As anything less than a tenure-track faculty member, there seems to be little opportunity for great advancement.

job_title: Principal Administrative Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The benefits (insurance and pension) are good. Unless you're a medical administrative assistant, as far as I've heard, people aren't overworked.  There is a lot to do -- book signings, activities to attend.
cons: The "U" is teeming with poor, power-tripping managers.  As stated above, merit is unacknowledged.  You rarely hear anything good but get raked over the coals over any little mistake.   As I've also read on another review, with which I concur, no matter how well you do and how much you keep your head down doing your job, the administrators find some way to undermine you.  It's very unprogressive with little interest in you advancing yourself or even learning any new skills.  Most managers have a (very undeserved) superiority complex. Many of them even utilize their own favored employees as "tattletales" and discuss other workers with these individuals -- so petty and unprofessional.

review_title: Direct supervisor(s) will make or break your experience here
pros: Great benefits, a lot of pride associated with the name, lots of opportunities of professional development and growth.
cons:
1) Low pay. 
2) Like many state jobs, the environment (for administrative staff) at the U of M breeds and rewards laziness and inefficiency. There is NO incentive to work hard, be innovative, or develop professionally (unless you plan to leave and take your skills elsewhere). You will be "rewarded" with more work (not higher pay) while your co-workers sit idly by making roughly the same salary. 
3) Low pay.

pros: Overall the University has good commitment to its employees. It is diverse and inclusive. Personal experiences vary WIDELY depending on the unit/department/program in which you work. Some are great, others are horrible. Pay also varies widely based on unit, but HR is trying to equalize across the institution based on job roles. Steer clear of the Alumni Association.
cons: Large decentralized university, lots of political maneuvering at the administrative level which can negatively impact actual working employees. Very poor leadership and cultural environment at the Alumni Association - no opportunity for advancement - Machiavellian leadership style - heads down environment - high turnover. Steer clear at this time.

pros: Benefits, location, student workers, colleagues, the good work and research they do with the smaller departments and schools.
cons:
Old school management/'leadership'. Just because something was done a certain way 25 yrs ago does not mean it's applicable in today's environment.  Boomer workers highly threatened by the next generations' work ethic, ideals and ideas. Not open to change. Expect to retain the their status quo no matter if it compromises the whole department. Don't encourage professional development. Don't promote or encourage employees to grow professionally. 
Plus who can possibly want to work for an organization with no integrity? ie the latest scandal with the U of M football team. Talk about cognitive dissonance!

review_title: Toxic Work Environment: No Action Taken
pros: Benefits, incredible research, fantastic facilities, and inspirational history.
cons: Toxic work environment not confronted by administration after various employees are forced to leave their jobs due to the said work environment. This comes after the UMN made the news for an abusive professor who was, not fired, but punished following a separate and damning case of abuse. I am currently finding support speaking with a grad student who was forced to leave due to the viciously homophobic treatment of a superior.  — HR and Chairperson exceptionally well informed. The UMN took no action.

review_title: A great place to semi-retire, but a struggle for anyone seriously looking for career advancement.
pros: Great benefits, good work/life balance.  I particularly enjoyed the tuition benefit, which is excellent for anyone thinking about an advanced degree.  100% of your tuition (and many of your fees) are covered, but that would not be a reason to stay at the U after you've completed your degree.  I think a lot of people go to the U because of the proximity to their classes, get their degrees, make their connections, and move on.  I know many folks who have done just that.
cons: SO much red tape, a very "wait your turn" mentality, regardless of results delivered.  There is very little pay for performance at the U.  Everyone gets the same 3.25% raise each year, which is handed down by the Regents.

review_title: The U of MN is an okay place to work.  It is great if you like academia or the resources made available to you.
pros:
You get access to resources that are available only to students, staff, and faculty.
If you want a way to go back to school while earning a paycheck, the U of MN is a good option as the tuition benefit covers 75% of the tuition cost, although it is capped per year.
Reasonable room to move to other positions and to network with other professionals.
cons: Sometimes you can feel like you are just a number.  This probably varies from department to department though, as workloads vary significantly, and so do policies and personalities.

pros: The health insurance seems to be quite a bit cheaper than what my friends in others companies have to pay. The tuition benefits are nice & they're generally willing to let you modify your work hours if you want to take a class during normal business hours. I never have to stay late to finish things; most positions are strictly 40 hours/week.
cons: I think the salary is quite a bit lower than in for-profit companies. People have to be *really* incompetent to get fired. There is no incentive to strive for excellence, because there is no recognition for it; bonuses & promotions are pretty much non-existent. You know that as long as the budget doesn't get too much, you're going to get your annual 3% raise and that's it.

review_title: Academia can produce a weird culture
pros:
-Flexible hours (usually)
-Great benefits
-Tons of opportunity for advancement
-Job security driven by political will vs. market uncertainty
-Tons of resources if you know where to look
-Open-minded culture
cons:
-Certain departments are critically understaffed to be effective
-(Tenured) Professor's as managers tend to be highly politically and egotistically driven
-Stagnant pay unless you change jobs a lot
-"Lifers" can be difficult to motivate
-Too large of an organization to manage consistently

review_title: Statesman: good experience if you make it one.
pros: Great journalism experience for anyone wanting to dip their toes into the field. Worked on sports, where I wanted to, and developed my communication, writing, and interviewing skills. Helped develop contacts on campus as well, as I was meeting with the basketball coaches, parking director, and a whole host of random people. Gave a great perspective into print journalism.
cons: Obviously the pay wasn't very good, a bit of a joke (almost wished it was just volunteer hours). The editors were cranky at times as well, and didn't run a story I wrote based on internal politics. The editors didn't communicate very well with the writers, and although I felt like a did a pretty good job in the Spring of 2008 I wasn't even sent an email asking if I would come back in the Fall.

pros: Education benefits are good. Easy to work in classes during the day. Nice campus and fun location. Fairly easy to innovate if its an effective solution.
cons: Pay is below average for IT workers. Centralization efforts are not well coordinated between university departments. Some people are "lifers" and very set in their ways, although there are some very intelligent and creative people who also enjoy the university environment. Staffing strategies are strange and people are not always appropriately assigned.

pros: Benefits are great. Co-workers enjoy their work and make for a fun environment to work in. Cross-unit collaboration can sometimes be rare but is always enjoyable and rewarding. Working on a college campus makes for a lively and dynamic environment in which to work.
cons: It seems easy to get "stuck" in a position and have nowhere to go. Feel expendable at times. Employees seem to be paid based on the number of degrees they hold and not based on the work they actually accomplish. It can be frustrating to be denied full cost-of-living raises and the full Regents Scholarship and yet see fiscal waste regularly around the U.

job_title: Principal Accounts Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: This was a great first full-time work experience.  I learned a lot about my department and the University.
cons: The pay was pretty low, even compared to other departments within the University.  There are not a lot -- or any -- room for advancement.  The job can get boring after you are trained in & efficient.  It is a lot of paper pushing.

review_title: Under-market pay; union dues; budget cuts.
pros: The University covers 100% of your tuition for your first undergraduate degree.  The University will also cover 75% of subsequent undergraduate degree(s), or a master's degree.
cons: Depending on the unit/department in which you are employed, you may be offered a salary well under market standards.  There is no getting out of union dues for civil service or bargaining unit employees, regardless of whether you support the union contract for your classification.  Due to budget cuts, even exemplary employees are subject to layoffs.

review_title: Lots of “haves” and many more “have nots.”
job_title: Information Technology Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Educational environment, lots of offerings (ie rec center, cafes, clinic, shopping) onsite.  Fun to be part of an organization that has a football team and marching band!
cons: Extremely political environment, very bureaucratic, top brass gets paid well, most others are paid below market—something that the institution seems to be proud of.  Everyone pays premium price for parking (and bus passes).  Employees are largely disengaged as management likes to take surveys on engagement but rarely (if ever) follows up on the feedback given.  Benefits were slashed during a period when employees were being provided a “Cadillac“ plan.  So now benefits and pay are both mediocre.

job_title: Senior Professional and Administrative (P&A) Role in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Laid back, casual work environment
Tuition benefit
City location, easy access via bus
Great place to coast and/or make a career transition
Lots to see and do on campus
Nice co-workers
cons:
No sense of urgency or vision
Pay for parking
Not into virtual meetings, so you have to walk or drive everywhere (which can take as long as the meeting itself)
Dependent on state budget
Performance evaluation is meaningless, everyone gets the same increase
Not easy to negotiate salary based on merits -- everyone in similar positions is paid the same
No rewards or recognition for risk taking or innovation
Easy to get stuck in a role, no clear career progression
Below-market compensation
Lots of "lifers" make it difficult for someone from the outside to come in (especially from private industry) and make an impact

review_title: Comforting or sufficating? Depends who you are.
pros:
Fantastic Benefits
Stimulating Environment
Good Coworkers
Good job security
cons:
Very difficult career advancement
Low pay and poor raises
Poor middle management
Expensive parking

pros: Easy to move within the University. Good benefits. Ok pay and decent vacation time with accrual.
cons: Sick time is lacking at 12 days per year. This does not increase. After time your vacation will accrue well after several years. I have about 22 days. They recently changed their job codes and basically ruined the best thing about the benefits, a very healthy matching amount for matching for retirement. Too much "bloat" for administration so they shuffled people around and cut off the possibility for advancement for a lot of folks. Their maternity leave can be 6 weeks paid (great) or only 2 weeks (shameful).

pros: Some of the best reasons to work at the University of MN are the students, staff and faculty. The campus is diverse and there are so many things to be involved in across the campus. The resources are endless and rarely a day passes that doesn't offer a new opportunity.
cons: With the above said, there are areas of the University that have horrible culture, are disrespectful to their staff, dismissive of diversity and generally oppressive conditions. This may be a surprise to some, but when you consider the staffing types needed to run the University it probably goes with out saying that certain industries bring their culture with them and it is further encouraged by the management in these areas.

review_title: A good university in a good society
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
It has a very rich academic environment with high tech facilities for any type of research. There are good programs for graduate studies in various fields. Therefore, lots of collaboration is happening between different groups in different departments.
There are people from different cultures in the city and also in the university which add diversity to the society. People are accepting to foreign people from different cultures.
cons:
Winter weather is harsh, but tolerable. There is lots of exaggeration about Minnesota weather.
It is a quiet city relatively lower public events relative to Chicago and Madison.

job_title: Student Personnel Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent benefits package (health, dental, vacation/sick time, retirement plans are all stellar!), personal opportunities for growth and development due to how large organization is, the feeling that you are actually making a difference in the lives of the students you serve
cons:
Tight budgets can often mean that the positions of employees who retire are not re-filled. Their work load, however, doesn't go away and is simply re-distributed and absorbed by the remaining employees. This creates work loads for full-time employees that are well above 40 hours per week. 

Salary can be much lower than comparable positions in the private sector, but the quality of the benefits package makes up for this many times over.

pros: Working for a major university and the university benefits
cons: DO NOT work for Executive Education at the Carlson School in any role. A mess all the way around and those who work at the U and have to deal with Exec Ed know this. It's a small, mostly unknown department that has been unprofitable and misled for years causing stress, turnover, and office culture issues at all levels within the department. Nobody trusts each other and nobody truly enjoys working there (though they may pretend to). Highly political with people constantly making it known what they've accomplished at work just to survive. Passive aggressiveness and disingenuousness is prevalent at all levels - workers, mid level, and leadership . One former exec literally left on vacation and never came back. Please save yourself the headaches and hassle and work someplace else. Not worth it for any amount of money.

pros: The University of Minnesota can be a great, energizing place to work, but a lot depends on the particular college you land in—some are better organized (and better funded) than others. But on the whole, the benefits are solid (particularly retirement benefits), most coursework is paid for, if it relates to your job, and I rarely, if ever, took work home with me.
cons: As in most large organizations, there's a lot of byzantine bureaucracy that you have to work your way through if you want to get anything significant done. There's also a bit of a "us/them" wall between staff and the professors (again, this differs between colleges). Finally, opportunities for advancement aren't always readily evident or available. There tends to be a fair amount of hopping between colleges and departments to circumvent this.

review_title: A slow paced and extremely independent work culture
pros: A lot of job opportunities and availability to find a very specific niche that you want to work in since the University is so large.
cons: The cons are definitely that since the University is so large that everything is very systematic and slow which includes a lot of procedures.  It is also so big that you sort of get swallowed up in the entire system and really only do your part and never really understand the whole picture of how the university works.

review_title: Overall ... a great place to work
pros:
(1)  The benefits are amazing.  Large employer contributions to your retirement plans.  Health Insurance that is incredible (I had to be in the hospital for several days) and I never saw a bill.
(2)  A relaxed work environment.  Yes, there are deadlines and fires to put out.  But, that corporate mentality just isn't here.
(3)  How many other people can say that their employer has a marching band.
cons:
(1)  it takes a long time for things to get done ..... and I mean LOOONNNGGGG.
(2)  It is hard to advance within the organization.  Instead of just saying "we are moving you over to this position now because we have an opening and you'd be great at it," they have to gather a candidate pool and hold multiple round of interviews.

pros: The educational experience was very strong. The university's reputation will help me in my job search. I think I am well-prepared on the material in my field. The overall university is making efforts to make a more diverse student body more welcome and better supported.
cons: Depending on the student's circumstances, my department is not a supportive environment for people traditionally underrepresented in this field.

pros:
It is good paying for a part-time student job. Also they have some desk shifts that allow you to work on some study so sometimes it is convenient.
Switching shift is easily done with your college and if you want a lot of hours, you could possibly have more than 80 hours a week/
In addition, you could gain training for law enforcement and it will be great addition for you entry-level resume.
cons: Most of the shifts are from 9 or 11 pm and end at 4 or 6 am. It is dead hours job so it will mess up you sleeping schedule and since it is in Minnesota, sometimes you have to walk in negative 40 degrees outside for more than hours.

job_title: Info Tech Manager Level I in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Benefits here are great, good vacation and sick leave policies and the health care is great
cons: This used to be a great place to work, but lately the workload has more than doubled, management refuses to hire more people, yet still expect high quality work.  I had a supervisor just recently tell me that I should be expected to work 70-80 hours a week.   Work/Life balance is asenine.   Supervisor will not allow my group to go to any training stating that it doesn't make sense for them to pay for training so that people leave.

review_title: A Great University on a Great Lake.
pros: Working for the University of Minnesota Duluth campus has been a great opportunity to enhance my leadership and communication skills. Students have the flexibility they need with work hours as well as many chances to get recognized in the work environment. It has also been beneficial to work in teams because that will no doubt be an important aspect in one's career.  Also, the summers in Duluth are hard to match; they are absolutely incredible.
cons: Besides the obvious cold weather, the cons are only limited to the amount of effort you decide to put in.  If you do not try and enjoy yourself, it will show through your work and employers/peers will see that.

pros: Union position. Flexible hours. Good Benefits.
cons:
President Kaler does not respect much less acknowledge the unions, the core of the UM.
Hours are flexible until they don't rehire for people that move on. Then they expect you to do the work of 3 people. OT not paid, tho they are legally required to do so.
They skirt the law as far as employee hours go.
Benefits are good now. Were better a few years ago. I expect the benefits to errode as Kaler continues reign.

review_title: For student workers: a decent way to get beer money
pros: The work usually isn't hard, the compensation is generally pretty good, there are lots of jobs available, generally, and the managers generally understand that you're a student first, and an employee second.
cons: Usually isn't always - sometimes students are relied on too much to staff critical roles in organizations, and that's not quite appropriate sometimes (like, say, finals week). There tends to be a frustratingly high ratio of bureaucracy to actual people who do things, which is a problem throughout the University.

review_title: Your experience will vary wildly depending on department and your PI
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I enjoy the opportunity to absorb lots of miscellaneous information through seminars and extracurricular activities which allows me to develop myself according to the priorities I set.
cons: University work often suffers from lack of structure and clearly defined goals. Or goals can be defined well but with no clear method on how​ to achieve them. I would also encourage students to work towards their own professional development as professors are sometimes lacking in support for this area.

job_title: Community Program Specialist/Clinical Research Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits. Great place to network with new people
cons: Takes too long to get a task completed. Too much red tape. There was no "orientation" that was specific to my position. I had to learn everything myself and find my own training sessions.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Department has students on RA - no TA requirement. Health insurance benefit is very good! Field research facilities for agriculture are top notch.
cons: A lot of red tape and hoops to jump through for simple tasks (i.e. hiring undergraduates takes 1 month on average and goes through 4-6 layers of HR). CFANS level administration keeps making cuts to departments and taking more funding from grants and non-sponsored funding. UMN is currently selling/developing the closest agricultural research station to the twin cities metro, making future ag-related research more difficult.

pros:
Great place to get my homework done and get paid for doing it!
They do a great job of working with your class schedule and allowing you to pick your own hours and the number of hours you want to work per week. They take seniority into consideration when putting together the schedule. Getting your shift covered is typically pretty easy since other students are always looking for more hours to get paid.
cons:
Typical student pay.
Having to deal with student athlete problems/drama/attitude isn't always fun.
You're pretty chained to your desk and they don't schedule in breaks or someone to cover your desk even if you've been working for more than 6 hours.
As the years have gone by shifts have shortened so that more students can be employed- I guess that is a pro and con.

review_title: Depending on your situation, the U of M can be a good employer for you.  Get the information up front however.
pros: Regents scholarship (provided your department lets you take more than the little known standard of one class), respectable employer, respectful management, homegrown employees, plenty of job opportunities.
cons: Regents scholarship bait and switch (allowed to take two or fewer courses instead of four courses), plenty of job opportunities...but your boss will find out if you apply for any of them and guess how their perspective of your reliability changes, job stability, and a commute nightmare.

pros: Very broad organization; many different sub-units that do many different things. It is not all books  and teaching. Very interesting architecture on many buildings makes walking around campus interesting.
cons: Campus is in the bad part of town; police are overburdened; crime around the workplace is an ongoing problem and danger.  Students leave their mark (vomit) all over the place.  Coming to work on Mondays in the winter is gross because shop owners don't chip the sidewalks clean.  The chunks just wear away as the week goes on.  Pretty disgusting and too common.

pros: The experience of working in college athletics is one of a kind.  Being able to see cities and other schools I never would've had an opportunity to was an experience I will look back fondly on.  Also having an opportunity to work with inspiring student athletes is rewarding.
cons: The Athletic Department is a mess.  Not a lot of direction and a bureaucratic mess.  While some sports receive more money for supplies (basketball, football, hockey) other sports are left with chicken scratch.  As with most college athletic departments, there are haves and have nots regarding pay for employees.

review_title: Overly concerned about image, not about the Art
pros: Steady work, average benefits, short commute
cons: Inconsistent management, management did not practice what they preached, did not activiely engage employees in any meaningful ways, did not inspire employees to take ownership, did not allow employees to work independantly, no room to advance in the organization, one department dictated to all other departments, talked a lot about work/life balance but did not follow through in any meaningful way. Dictated work to employees contrary to individual employees job description, punished employees for showing intitive and being good at their job.

pros: Participate in forward front research for causes which people truely believe in.  Helps to work in an academic setting where you are encouraged to learn and continue educating yourself.  In fact you are given free tuition to keep attending classes.  The amount of collaborations you can establish at the U is also a plus since they have so many good scientists.  Also, I feel good about what I do everyday.
cons: Opportunities to advance are limited, the parking is attrocious!  to get around paying I have to finaggle a system of parking and walk in the freezing cold.  Also, some of the systems are limited such as with HR.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Minnesota is a great research-based university that has a strong reputation in the academic world.  At Minnesota, you are surrounded by smart professors and grad students.
cons: Minnesota is a top university, but with such a large undergrad population, not all undergrads are as strong academically as you would like them to be.  The top students are very strong, but there can be a significant drop off.  This is different than a smaller more selective school whose entire student population is more homogenous in terms of quality.

review_title: U of MN is a great place to work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The University of Minnesota has a very flexible work schedule. You can get paid by direct deposit every 2 weeks. They offer competitive fellowships for graduate students, allowing me to graduate without student loans.
cons: The campus is constantly being renovated to attract new students, meaning lots of construction year round causing traffic delays and commuting problems. The football stadium is used both by the vikings and gopher football teams, as well as other stadiums for the other major sports that further congest traffic around the workplace.

review_title: Great campus, with sometimes frustrating old ways
pros: It's great to work on a beautiful college campus. The benefits are fantastic and must be considered when comparing base salaries with the private sector.
cons: The University is large and slow-moving. The non-academic side to the University is seriously lagging behind private sector workplaces. This has everything to do with the fact that it's a great place to work, so there is little turnover and new work practices are rarely introduced. Departments are very siloed, and upper management is competitive and political, resulting in a lack of collaboration and little drive to work together for common goals.

job_title: Laboratory Animal Attendant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Unbeatable insurance benefits. Generous vacation and sick PTO.  Regular yearly step raises guaranteed by union. Regular M-F schedule with no weekends or holidays necessary if you are high on the seniority list (although newer employees do have to work these shifts).
cons: Lots of red tape and managers managing the managers managing the managers managing you. Difficult and sometimes emotionally draining work, leading to high turnover.  Easy to feel unappreciated, and sometimes management and lab staff can be condescending. Few incentives to work hard and do a good job, which allows some co-workers to be lazy and not pull their weight, protected by the union. Very few opportunities for advancement, and those opportunities come with few incentives (much more work for a very small pay differential).

pros: Flexible schedule and hours - they understand you are a student, and don't want to impede your academic success.
cons: Sometimes you feel like a contracted grunt.  Pay could be higher - compensation for similar jobs at other companies is usually higher.  There needs to be some added benefit, monetarily or otherwise, to attract students to a job with the same responsibilities but lower pay.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tinley Park, IL
pros: It is a beautiful campus, and overall an okay place to work.  Benefits were good, and the tuition discount is a great perk.
cons: I worked in an old building that had heat issues in the winter and air conditioning issues in the summer.  It also wouldn't be unusual to come in and see roaches in the hallways.  Garage parking is expensive, and the alternative is parking further out and waiting for the shuttle or walking in.  In the summer it's not a bad option, but in the winter, it can be tough.

pros: Academic freedoms translate to somewhat flexible management of employees.  Experience really depends on manager to which report.
cons: Lower salaries than in business world.  Benefits not any better than corporate benefits packages.  HR function, hiring, and related processes are completely a mess.

review_title: Good place to gain job experience
pros:
Great health benefits
Flexible work hours
Interesting environment to work in; little time to be bored.
Lots of ideas floating around
Semi casual dress code!
cons:
It takes forever to get a project moving.
Very little clarity on job duties (ie structure within a department). There's so much overlap and randomness it's sometimes hard to figure out who to contact for what.
Sometimes little clarity on what an end result should look like.

review_title: Decent Assistantship at a 4 year public research university
pros: Great healthcare coverage and tuition benefits.  I had an awesome supervisor who was really supportive of my developing professionally.
cons: Unless you have a great supervisor like I did, experiences can vary in terms of work direction. Also Some grad students are pushing to unionize which in my opinion was frustrating because the structure of assistantships at the U varies by department and is not run by the top tiers of university administration.

review_title: Numerous opportunities to grow in any field.
pros: Office environment is always bright and cheerful. There's always a way to get the learning experience you want, you just have to ask around. Employers are always willing to lend a hand in finding a job that fits your interests.
cons: Depending on where you work you might have to take things in your own hand to get where you want or to improve your work environment. Employers are flexible with when you take time off just need to notify your employer a week or two in advance as courtesy and send an email as reminder.

pros: Lots of great people, smart, capable and friendly.
cons:
Salaries are usually low compared to the private sector, especislly if no private sector equivalent position for competition.
The quality of unit, department or school management is highly variable.
Some of the departments, centers and administrative units are quite good while others can be very toxic.
Status and heirarchy are much more apparent on average than in industry/private sector.
Parking is terrible...
Federal and State funding continues to stagnate, many structural problems need to be resolved.
A refuge for many difficult personality types.

review_title: Good place to get the feet wet.
pros: The pay is fair for the work and it is an opportunity to learn and grow in an educational environment.  It also gave me an opportunity to work with career professionals who knew had connections outside of the educational and academic field in order to help further progress my career to other places.
cons: The position that I held did not pay well, although understandably.  There is somewhat of a disconnect between academic institutions and the real world that can become an annoyance after being in the environment for a while.  Also, some projects that I worked on seemed to never come to fruition because funding was discontinued.

pros:
Regents scholarship pays for 75% of graduate school tuition.
Great health and retirement benefits.
cons: For people who work in "business functions", aka non-faculty or student affairs positions (communications, finance, IT, etc) there is close to no upward mobility, very little room for growth, and the pay isn't that great. People who are actually talented within these functions don't stay very long. There are layers and layers of bureaucracy that need to be gone through in order to make decisions. Overall, I would not recommend working at the UMN for a business function unless you're there to get your Master's degree. Compensation-wise, it's just not worth it.

pros:
*Health insurance is unmatched in the market 
*If classified as P&A, retirement benefits are unmatched in the market (10% match)
*Transparent salaries – look up job code pay class before accepting offer, all salaries are public
*40 hour weeks or less 
*It's easier to transfer around the University system once you're hired into it.
cons:
*Completely disorganized leadership 
*Extremely high turnover rate, re: above point, and low morale 
*Embarrassing facilities and working conditions, lack of physical space or amenities like parking for employees at CFANS
*Extremely siloed teams, non-collaborative mentality, "not my job" way of thinking
*Lack of professional development opportunities
*Dearth of expertise across the college, most employees have never worked outside of academia to acquire competitive/current skills

pros: Great benefits and environment is friendly. No boss breathing over your neck.  I rather enjoyed working here.  i was given a list of expectations and tasks and I was able to complete them easily.
cons: It was a temporary position and I couldn't extend it further. Post ions depend on grants and there is not much job security unless you are a tenure track faculty.. but I guess this is true of most higher education institutions.

review_title: Wonderful and very flexible with class schedule
job_title: Assistant to Customer Service (Student Worker) in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The office environment at the University of Minnesota Networking and Telecommunication department is very flexible for the student workers they hire. My managers and other employees were always very approachable and LOVED showing you how to do things and were always very appreciative of any help they received from the student workers. Plus the office did fun lunch activities like chili contests and pot lucks. What student worker (or any employee for that matter) doesn't like free food!?
cons: Like with any large company some changes can be slow to implement. Parking is awful but if you have a good pair of shoes it shouldn't be a problem.

review_title: Unorganized, lack of structure, not enough coordination between research centers
pros:
Flexible schedule
Good benefits
Nice transitional job between grad school and the real world
cons:
Non-negotiable salary 
Dated research topics
Research is politically driven

pros: Terrific benefits, nice gym, mostly relaxed atmosphere. Very beautiful urban campus, very convenient to residences, events, theater, sports. Good transit, parking okay. Usually well funded.
cons: Sloppy organization, bad management at both the middle and upper layers. Everything is accomplished by who-you-know, not by any kind of consistent process. Provincial attitudes. And of course the weather, absurdly hot in the summer, ridiculously cold in the winter. Job application process is Kafkaesque.

review_title: Great people and great benefits but terrible pay.
pros: The people and work environment are exceptionally positive and satisfying.  People seem genuinely engaged and committed to working together to create efficient and successful results.  The benefits are absolutely wonderful!  They enable an individual to advance through the acquisition of additional degrees and certificates as well as take care of basic medical and dental coverage.
cons: The compensation with regards to pay is absolutely terrible.  It is not competitive with other universities and colleges in the region and certainly not competitive with the private sector.  Higher administration consistently stymies contract negotiations causing a lower than average beginning salary, wage freezes, and furloughs every few years for those union positions.

pros: A great laid-back atmosphere. There was undesirable work to do, but it was low stress on loose deadlines. Long lunches at nearby restaurants are very nice. It's a government job, so once you're out of probation it's next to impossible to be fired if you're competent. There weren't many secrets in my department and the larger organization was very transparent and communicated well. It's possible to set expectations and have a very decent work life balance (even while on-call 24/7... if you're good).
cons: The bureaucracy can be very annoying. Salaries are 30% lower than the technology job average.

job_title: Research Entomologist in Saint Paul, MN
pros: I've been fortunate to work on some really innovative projects, and most of the faculty share the view that not all research needs to have a goal of maximizing profits, and that basic science is necessary. The schedule can be pretty flexible depending on the faculty.
cons: There's such a lack of stability. The professor I was working for left, and I had a handful of people all telling me different things (that I was out of a job, that I was fine where I was and not to worry, that I had a few more weeks left....). Working from grant-to-grant can be very stressful.

review_title: Good place to work, but it all really depends on who your boss/what your project is
pros: The pros are that your tuition gets paid if you're in a research assistant position as a grad student, good experience, and good networking
cons: If you have a bad boss, the work can be unorganized and hectic. An example is your boss/professor not emailing you reports/files that need to be done until a day or two before which leads to a CRAZY stressful day or two. And unfortunately it happened to me a few times.

review_title: Great place to work for a student
pros:
Very flexible hours for student workers. Work-life balance is excellent -- if you need to study, it's always been easy to make time for that.

Also, this place looks great on your resume. I've gotten a few interviews for full time work at other places purely because I have this experience listed.

The culture is pretty laid back as well, in my experience.
cons: Sometimes not much to work to do. Also new initiatives sometimes get brought up by management, or some department will decide on a "new way of doing things" but these changes seem to sometimes get forgotten about. This does seem to be getting better lately, though.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Health insurance is good, and there's a lot of professional development opportunity.
cons:
Teaching assistants from different departments earn drastically different wages for essentially the same work, and at least in my department are barely trained at all before being unleashed on students. The current setup is unfair to both students and their graduate student instructors.
Additionally, $1600/month after taxes, while not the worst income offered to teaching assistants at UMN, is fairly difficult to live on.

job_title: Senior Patient Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: *Fair pay for your first year of employment
cons:
*Not a lot of opportunity for professional growth
*Horrible benefits
*After your first two years of employment the pay scale is inadequate
*Corporate philosophy does not seem to keep employees in mind (with the exception of the Physician staff).

pros: Working for the University of Minnesota has been great. The benefits are outstanding and the people are friendly. The work-life balance is unmatched to any other company I have been at.
cons: The pay is low but that is expected when working for the University. Also, there are a lot of people who just collect a paycheck and don't do much work. It's hard to stay motivated in an environment where you are not rewarded for hard word. Not a ton of opportunities for career advancement.

review_title: Great student jobs, could do with more advanced positions
job_title: Technology Help Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I worked for the Information Technology department of the UMN as a Technology Help Specialist. I liked the job a lot and the pay was fair. There were also plenty of hours available and most of my coworkers were great to work with.
cons: Need more student IT jobs that deal with software development and coding. Computer Science jobs on campus are hard to find and most UMN positions dealing with more complex stuff are full-time only.

review_title: Best Position Possible as a Master's Student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: This position has been amazing, as a current Master's student at the U. I get full tuition benefits, on top of a competitive hourly pay. Health insurance under the Graduate Assistant Insurance Plan is only around $100/semester, with free preventative care and $10 copays otherwise. My office is full of smart, warm, and dedicated employees, and my direct supervisor has been incredibly understanding of my need to balance my education with my work. Professional development opportunities abound.
cons: The U of M, as with most institutions of higher education, can get bogged down in bureaucracy. Obviously, at such a large institution, experiences will vary greatly depending on departments and supervisors.

pros:
Mission-driven, making a difference in peoples' lives
Outstanding health and wellness benefits
Generous retirement benefits
On many express bus lines and Green Line
cons:
Constant financial scarcity in many units contributes to lower morale. Financial resources are generally unevenly distributed.
Budget outlook is grim for the next few years. Although only 16% or so of budget comes from Legislature, it's an important chunk of money and elected officials use their personal beliefs re: fetal tissue research or the value of higher ed in general to punish the University.

pros: Bosses are nice if you're in the right departments, work life balance is great, academic setting is always educational and challenging everyday, surrounded by intelligent people makes you smarter, great place to work for if you enjoy kids and students and teaching.
cons: The pay isn't the best in the world, it's hard to move up the ladder. The U is big, so you won't get to know a lot of the people you work for. Politics.

pros: Energetic work environment; competitive yet supportive.  Encourages scholarly activity and clinical skill advancement.  Positive leadership that looks to advancement of all their faculty members.
cons: High level and focus on obtaining NIH or similar level of grants; in today's competitive environment and shrinking pot of federal funding, this can be frustrating at times.  Long work weeks, including nights and weekend.

pros: Easy work, 75% getting your next degree or 100% off your 1st.
cons: Decentralized,  meaning some crazy old white man or women is likely in charge, thinks they are god, and they took a typing test to get the job.  Along the same lines, good luck moving up.

review_title: Great place to work for the benefits
pros: Good benefits with good management of the States MSRS fund. Many medical benefits to choose from in an area that delivers excellent health care.
cons: Many of the jobs in science can be temporary based on your Private Investigators funding. You may end up changing jobs many times if you want to keep employed in the science field.

pros: There's a lot of team work in the Athletics Department,  and the people you work with are for the most part really great. Health insurance is fantastic.
cons: There is no upward mobility, the management either has very little clue how unhappy the staff is  or doesn't care. You will make significantly less than you would working for a private company or even elsewhere on campus.

pros: Minnesota has a fantastic benefits program.  In my department, we have an excellent, collegial environment that encourages people to do their best.  As with any tenure profession, there is pressure, but my department, and the College of Science and Engineering has proven time and time again that they want their junior faculty to succeed by  providing all of the resources possible to  enable my research.
cons: There are pressures of academic life, but the University of Minnesota has done everything I can think of to mitigate those.  The only con I can think of is that our salary is lower than other Big 10 comparable universities

review_title: A very positive experience with a low salary but full health care and a relaxed atmosphere.
pros: A very laid back environment that was comfortable in which to work. I enjoyed working with my colleagues and when I left the university, my co-workers and superiors said I'd be greatly missed.
cons: For the amount of work that a graduate instructor must do, aside from teaching and studying, there was an expectation to do more work and the compensation was not that great.

review_title: A massive bureaucracy chock-full of kind and innovative people doing interesting work
pros: The U of M truly strives - every day - to hold its rank as a top-10 public research university. Research and innovation are prominently celebrated, and campus-wide participation is encouraged and honored.
cons: The U of M is mind-bogglingly massive - the Minneapolis campus is four times the size of my entire home town, with 10 thousand employees and 50 thousand students. They just don't have the patience to hold your hand and coddle you through a career path, so you'll be expected to move your own career along with hard work and determination (and switching departments to get what you want).

job_title: Student Life Tech Assistant in Duluth, MN
pros: For college students, an on-campus job means no commute between classes and work, and a flexible schedule that lets you put your academics first. Pay is consistently above state minimum wage
cons: Being a student worker means there is very little chance to advance your position, as you are limited by hours and the student status. It is also very difficult to find jobs that are not earmarked for Work/Study students, which means you could be unable to find a job on campus due to your parent's income.

review_title: Pharmacology department scientist and lab manager dealt with GIRK channels, drug addiction and rodents.
pros:
Great for independence and flexibility in both research and time management. 
Could learn anything you wanted in terms of what went on in the lab.
cons:
Salary was too low for the work being done. $30,000.  But this is normal in academia I am learning.
Often worked 7 days a week because animals were involved and cell culture etc.
This is fine if you don't have a family but when a family is involved its too much especially for the salary.

pros: It worked out well with being a student, picking up part time work.  It was easy to live in the same place as you work, because you can pick up morning shifts or late night shifts and just walk back up to your room and fall asleep. That was very nice.
cons: The pay isn't great, and it could be tought to get hours.  You would meet and based on seniority go around the room to block out 2-4 hours in the week that you worked.  Even if you had seniority, it could be tough getting enough good hours to work.

pros: Some of the  most wonderful people work in the AHC.  But they are the part time adjunct faculty.  Easy access to campus.
cons: Adjunct faculty grossly underpaid.  Expected to put in 150% for 20, 30, 40, or 60% pay.  Never got a raise, promotion as stated in employee handbook-even with excellent work record.  Always asking taxpayers for more money to fund high administration and coaching salaries.  If there is a tuition freeze, it's because people have been fired.

review_title: Strong research university, but need more quality control for teaching
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: They offered courses assisting international students with their language and teaching skills. It helped get me prepared for the job. I also enjoyed lots of autonomy while leading recitation session or teaching a course.
cons: With more enrollment, the workloads increases a lot, but the salary stayed almost the same. There were few measures to ensure the quality of teaching. I once substituted for a professor, and a student came up, saying that it was the only class in which she got something, and what I did was only explaining all the necessary concepts and demonstrating the examples in the book.

job_title: Department Accountant/Executive Account Specialist in Cloquet, MN
pros: This was a good job, solid if you made it past state budgeting lay-offs.  That time of year was always nerve-wrecking!  Good benefits.  Most people were great to work with and for.
cons: There were some bad parts.  Lots of politics.  Some people had agendas.  Very liberal.  Not a lot of room to advance.  It is basically a place to work the rest of your life and then collect a pension.  It wasn't for me.  I got my education, had aspirations, and then left.

review_title: Challenges and benefits of working at the U
job_title: Assistant Department Director in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Employees are allowed to apply to take courses for free.  The benefits are very good.  Insurance, retirement, etc. are a big reason many work here.  Working in an institution of higher learning is great.  The students have a lot of energy, are bright, and fun to work wtih.  It's also exciting to be around continuous learning and people interested in learning.
cons: The pay is not great for the number of hours/workload expected.  The expectations within our school are very different than other parts of the University.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good balance between academic and professional responsibilities, generous compensation, supportive faculty and staff members.
cons: Tuition is high for a public school. The culture within the departments I worked was very cliquish, making it difficult sometimes to get things done. Everyone seems to have their own territory when it comes to classes. The administration don't always communicate effectively with the graduate students.

pros:
Relaxed atmosphere.
High autonomy (in certain areas).
Good availability of shared IT resources.
Flexible remote working options.
cons:
Things can take a long time to change. Many meetings are needed to make decisions and build consensus.
No employer-match elective retirement contributions.
You experience may vary! Different departments and groups have a lot of autonomy, so there are many different work cultures throughout the system. Experience with one group may not offer any insight into how another operates.

pros: There was flexibility in my schedule.
cons:
Worst professional experience after 10+ years of working. I was in a grant-funded area within the Academic Health Center but was a full-time employee of the University. Leadership was narcissistic and out-of-touch. 

Every aspect of your work was micro-managed. Meetings would turn into screaming matches if the director and assistant director didn't agree. I was asked to falsify information in a report.  I called University's ethics hotline  and no one followed up with me. 

In 13 months, more than 60% of staff had quit. I'm sure not all areas of the University are like this, but there from what I witnessed, stroking egos was more important than results.

pros: scheduling time off, benefits are good but going in the wrong direction.
cons: OIT senior management team are all going different directions, it is comical to see them all stand up in front of us at all staff meetings, each one looks painfully forced to stand as one team because they all have different views on how this organization should be run...we know they tend dislike each other.

pros: I feel that my pay is very fair, and I have been rewarded with raises for meeting goals. However, it seems that these experiences vary greatly for different people depending on the department, the supervisor, and the position.
cons: Administrative staff can seem very incompetent. Policies regarding employment are very different from department to department, and each seems to expect you to learn by trial and error, even if that means missing pay periods.

review_title: Awesome if you love to learn new things.
pros: U of M provides friendly and supportive environment to work in and lots of opportunities to learn new skills. I is not very stressful job but that might depend on what lab you are in and who is your PI.
cons: Getting there if difficult, parking is very expensive and very far from where the labs are, busses are inconvenient and will waste a lot of your time, and still will cost almost as much as some of the far away parking lots (at least for the staff, it is much cheaper for students and faculty).

pros: Excellent work life balance, excellent benefits, and opportunities for growth if your willing to leave your current department.
cons: Some departments offer less salary then the going rate for information technology positions.  IT was put into silo's for each area in the main IT community and that makes it difficult to accomplish projects unless you have every player at the table and that is usually very difficult to accomplish.  Help desk calls get passed from one person to another to another rather then getting solved

pros: Institutional benefits are quite solid, good vacation, fair-ish salary, and campus itself is quite lovely. I've seen more departments committed to a work-life balance than in many environments
cons: Supervisors often have little or no training and very few offices have a talent development perspective. Taking the next step in your career ladder may take 30 years or may never happen.

review_title: Good Company; Abusive employers allowed to persist
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
- benefits package
- PhD fully paid for
- Resources for scientific research
- Competent mentors and coworkers are there if you look for them
cons:
- Primary Investigators face no real consequences for abusive behavior
