- HR is an absolute joke; you can report inexcusable behavior (ie. sexual harassment, toxic employee behavior, racist aggression) and expect nothing to be done

review_title: Review of my employment at the U
pros:
The benefits package is attractive.  Some of the highlights include the solid medical and dental plans, the Regent's scholarship for tuition, and the wellness programs to reduce medical plan  costs for those who wish to participate.  The campus is very attractive with historic buildings, a beautiful mall area, and the vibrancy of its population.  There are great places to eat in Coffman Union, Dinkytown and Stadium Village. 
The University truly is like a little city onto itself, with medical facilities, a veterinary clinic, education (obviously), fitness centers, post offices, and just about every other amenity you can imagine!
cons:
The University is plagued with issues that affect just about every other college, and then it has it's own sets of problems.
First, the institution is decentralized to the point that it is essentially crippled when it comes to making key decisions that can transform a process.  Every unit/department believes that their agenda is THE most important, and those units (no matter how small) can kill an important initiative that could potentially benefit about 99.99% of the university.  Basically, the squeeky wheel wins, OFTEN.  
Second, there are many high level administrators who use schmoozing and friendships as their guiding light when it comes to hiring and decision making , rather than using insightful analysis, expert input, and data driven strategies. 
Third, as is the case in most higher education institutions (at least one would assume), tenured faculty are treated like royalty, meaning that they are often allowed to get away with verbally abusing staff, flagrantly ignoring policies, and creating costly headaches for university administration.  
Finally, there are the well known, embarrassing scandals of ivory tower priviledge..  the US Bank Stadium VIP boxes being used by high level athletics administrators, the former CIO using funds for personal expenses, the Psychiatry scandal... 

All of these can make the university a very frustrating bubble to inhabit.  There is alot passion, but there is also alot of ego, entitlement, and priviledge.  It takes a thick skin to work there, at all levels... from individual contributor to administrator.

review_title: Great entry-level position, but not a lot of opportunities for growth
pros: The benefits are extremely wonderful in addition to holidays and vacation time.  The campus is like a miniature town with lots of activities and places to walk.
cons: The UMN is a very complex organization and with that said, many career paths are undefined and people often are unsure where they can "go next".  I currently do not feel there are growth opportunities, but those looking to have good benefits and okay pay without advancement might find this a desirable place to work.

review_title: Reasonable arrangement for graduate students in mathematics.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Tuition is covered.  Administration is very helpful.  If you don't have your own funding, you are guaranteed a TA position with a small stipend for six years.  Teaching responsibilities take about 12-15 hrs/week, leaving you with enough time for coursework and research.  Flexible summers.  Good community of students.
cons: Stipend runs around 18k, does not include health insurance - difficult to live on for six years.  Job prospects after graduation are always in flux.  Advisers are hit-and-miss.

pros: Flexible work hours, good benefits (health and dental), most laboratories have a relaxed atmosphere, location is fine most of the time
cons: If you are academic staff (graduate student, postdoctoral fellow, etc.) you will be working all. the. time. Your weekends, Thanksgivings, Christmases, New Years, Memorial Days, etc. will be spent in a laboratory, and your evenings will be spent doing work from home.

pros: Working at a world class university is very rewarding. For people in IT, there is a great deal of freedom to experiment with new technology. The IT community is relatively close-knit. The size of the University (nearly $4 billion operation budget and nearly 25,000 full-time employees) rivals that of many of the country's largest corporations and presents many interesting IT challenges.
cons: There is a culture of passive-resistance that can make it difficult to get new ideas adopted. No one cares if you try new things but it's hard to get good ideas adopted. Salaries are generally less than the private sector for comparable work.

review_title: Outstanding graduate research at the CEMS department; one of the best; many interdisciplinary research opportunities
pros:
Outstanding department and researchers
Lots of interdisciplinary research
Department is competitive, (this could be good or bad!)
Super characterization facility for experimentalists
Strong theory base
Among the best pays at the U for grad students
Relocation allowance
Most profs want you to succeed
Interaction (+ placements!) in industry through IPRIME
Good city, lots of activities in the U
Has fantastic arts college, medical school so that life doesn't get one dimensional for techies
cons: Weather is not great -- can pull spirits down at times, needs time to adjust

review_title: The university dining services at the University of Minnesota-Great
pros:
This review is about the university dining services at the University of Minnesota -Twin Cities. University Dining Services is an organization run by the University of Minnesota and the Aramark food services. It has been established to cater the food needs of the students at U. All the dining halls, restaurants and food courts run under this brand name called "'University Dining Services"
Free food
In the heart of university
Many options to choose from
cons:
The following are the cons. Actually I could not think of any cons.These can be fixed if you talk to your manager.
Non Flexible timings.
Odd hours.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good campus, nice buildings and equipped gym, nice health and dental insurance.
cons: The work/life balance for graduate students is terrible especially in hard sciences such as Physics and Astronomy. There is almost no control on the student/advisor interactions.  If you're lucky and work with a good advisor then good for you. If faculties doesn't care about their graduate students or can't guide them then the poor student will be blamed for everything.

pros: Besides the beautiful campus and great facilities, the U has world-class professors committed to training the next generation of scientist, engineers, doctors, etc. I was paired with a great advisor and have had the opportunity to learn and develop research skills I will use for the rest of my career.
cons: The winters in Minnesota can be brutal, especially if you are from the south. I was born in a temperate climate, and I still found MN winters to be harsh. One should be prepared for the weather and embrace it before one decides to embark on a 4+ year journey at UMN.

pros: Great health benefits including full coverage of mother's and new baby's hospital stay.  The reimbursement for graduate courses was 75%.  Pension plan and 403B.  Provided ergonomic workstations including desks that went up and down.
cons: Assigned to a "civil servant" job class which has strict guidelines as what can be performed in your daily duties.  Have to pay for parking.

review_title: Expect to be not paid your worth if you are support staff
pros: Free tuition if you are obtaining your first bachelor's degree.
cons:
Must pay for parking currently about $70-100 dollars a month.
Support staff (including mangers that are union backed) are under appreciated and under paid.
Incivility from those who consider themselves to be higher educated - often treating others like peasants.
Support staff wages do not even keep up with cost of living, so do not plan on working here for a long time without working your way up the ladder.

review_title: University of Minnesota Job Satisfaction Determined by Your Needs
job_title: Senior IT Professional in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
The biggest pros for working at the U of M relate to work/life balance.  This list is from Civil Service perspective, this job group represents about 30% of employees:
1. Excellent benefits for you and your family
2. A lot of time off, even in entry level jobs (3 weeks and in some jobs 4 weeks)  and if you work there a long time 10-20 years the length of time off can reach 6-8 weeks and people do use the vacation.
3. Typically very casual in terms of dress codes and general demeanor of people.
4. Great education benefits for you, none for family.  Basically you pay 25% tuition, this just changed, you used to pay 0%.
5. Once you're in, moving around the University and trying different positions is easier than other places.

In general it's a great place to work if you are at a stage in life where family is very important or you need that flexibility of a low stress job that pays ok and has great benefits.
cons:
Cons is a difficult word.  Many of these aren't cons, but rather trade-offs for the benefits listed under pros.
1. Pay is generally lower by 10-30% then you are going to see in private sector, in IT for sure.  Some people might make more based on higher minimum salaries, but if you are a professional anything expect to make less.
2. People never leave.  If you are looking to move into management, these positions can be filled by people who have worked at the U for 10-20 years and might not leave for 10-20 more.  Expect to change positions or college/unit to get a promotion.
3. This organization is consensus based.  Decisions can be drawn out and lots of analysis required to do anything and this can drive some people crazy. Some people love it. 
4. Parking is bad, not as bad as downtown but bad.

pros: Some pros of working at the University of Minnesota are a relaxed pace, a lot of interesting folks around doing great research, and an incredible variety of opportunities. Job security is also pretty good for most people.
cons: Depending on where exactly you land a position, you may not be particularly challenged in your job. If you look around though, you can definitely find something that works for you. Because it's a huge bureaucracy, you have to be willing to get out of your own department and find opportunities that can advance your career, they won't just fall in your lap.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great academic atmosphere, relaxed vibe mixed with prestigious academics. If you interested in doing challenging research with first rate professors but in a place with a little less of a competitive atmosphere, the U of M is a great place for you.
cons: University of Minnesota deserves a better name than it has. It's a top ten public university, and should be recognized as such.

review_title: Good benefits but POOR management, POOR career mobility
job_title: Principal Administrative Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good health insurance and pensions, flexibility with taking time off, always something interesting to do nearby.  Can take classes and have them partially or fully paid for.
cons: No career pathway to speak of.  Virtually impossible to move up.  Merit matters very little, a lot of favoritism and poor middle managers.  Hierarchical and dictatorial atmosphere.

pros:
Flexible schedule
Informal work community, mainly co-workers are students
Fast-paced environment (might be cons or pros, depends on your work style)
Learn a lot while working, always continually build knowledge of new products and service offerings
cons: Starters might get stressful at the first couple of weeks because you will get calls asking about XYZ issues that you have know idea. After that, specialists will get the hang of it as well as escalation technique

review_title: Not bad if you want a steady, easy, life-long job
pros:
The tuition benefits are amazing.  Had I really fallen in love with a graduate program, I would still work there just to finish a master's degree.  My supervisors allowed me to have a very flexible work schedule in order to attend class.

Health benefits are extensive and extremely affordable, and there are professional development and work counseling benefits as well (though whether or not you'll be able to apply them toward career advancement is a different story).

If you are Civil Service or Bargaining Unit, your job at the U can truly be a punch in - punch out 37.5 hours a week experience.  I never had to think about work outside of those 37.5 hours.  The 12:00-1:00 lunch hour is sacred.
cons:
Politics, politics, politics.  Office politics and bureaucratic red tape dominate all aspects of the University.  Career advancement was a joke, as the optimal University employee is one who stays in their position for 30+ years and simply takes the 1-3% annual salary increase.  As to be expected at a university, advanced degrees are a prerequisite for most non-data entry/office admin positions -- but politics tend to cloud hiring decisions (particularly those involving internal candidates).

The free tuition benefit doesn't look so appealing when you realize that other employers will pay you a higher salary that more than compensates for the (ever increasing) cost of tuition.

IT infrastructure is years behind the curve, and software projects take years upon years to complete.  Centralized data management is nonexistent, as University-wide and college-specific IT groups rarely interact or collaborate.  PeopleSoft and other database systems are tedious and inflexible, leaving most departments to use disparate Access databases and inefficient Excel spreadsheets to track vital departmental data.

job_title: Info Tech Professional in Minneapolis, MN
pros: If one can navigate around the bureaucracy, the opportunities for personal growth and discovery are immense. The University has many smart, talented people with whom to work, and there is an abundance of interesting problems that need to be solved.
cons:
- The University of Minnesota is a $2.5B enterprise with many layers of bureaucracy. Senior leadership, while decent folk, are not responsive and have a one-size-fits-all mentality when it comes to overseeing different domains of the University.

- There are limited pathways to advancement outside of supporting the enterprise. For many non-faculty members, working at the department level or a research lab is tantamount to the death of your career. The only way to advance in salary or position is to department hop.

- Wages have not kept up with the marketplace and total compensation (particularly fringe benefits) has eroded over time.

- The University has established hierarchy within the IT job family such that position (and thus salary) is determined by enterprise scope instead of the knowledge of the individual. The structure also perpetuates isolated technical tracks rather than fostering the development of a more holistic IT professional. As the nature of the work is increasingly interdisciplinary, the structure is incompatible with the demands of the job and fuels disparity amongst positions.

- The corporatization of the University is destroying its culture.

pros: Flexibility in time, various top-level research operations.  The gym is a 2 minute jog from my office.  I can get in at whatever time I wish, as long as I get my job done right.  I love that results-oriented environment.
cons: Low pay, little room for growth up the ladder.  Some of the people you will work with tend to be stuck in their roles and do not have the ambition to work harder.  Life is great for them and they don't have a pressured-bottom-line mentality that lives at a lot of companies.

job_title: Student Administrative Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The hours are incredibly flexible, you can pick your own hours as a student worker and priority is always given to school work. As a student worker you get all holidays off. Supervisors are incredibly friendly and easy going.
cons: Limited hours available to work in the summer if there are other student workers. There is also no room for growth or to expand within a student position

pros:
- The health, dental, education benefits are hard to beat. It's well known that they are one of the best in the state. 
- If you love working with students and education, of course it's a great place to be immersed in the lifestyle. 
- Resources! Resources! Resources! All basically at your fingertips! Pretty much anything that you would have as a resource if you were a student. Classes, healthcare, location, social groups, athletic facilities,  dining facilities, etc. You just have to be willing to work, play, live on campus if you want to take advantage of many of the offerings. 
- Rate of pay for a position like mine, plus the benefits,  is very good. 60-65K range. Many other institutions would likely pay at least 10-15k less.
cons:
Nothing will ever be perfect, but here are some of my cons. 
- You're paying your employer to go to work for them.  Parking and all public transportation options will cost you a minimum of $1200/year pre-tax if you're a full-time employee working on campus M-F 9-5. 
- The department in which I work is very disjointed, geographically as well as socially. The senior management conducts the office with very poor expectations, communication, motivation, sincerity for care of employees. The rate of turn over between teams is polar opposite. Some teams have nearly an 80% annual turn-over rate and others have teams that were born, bred, and will die here... but some of those teams are the most unproductive and archaic... just sliding by until retirement.

pros:
The people in my unit that I work with and an atmosphere of openness to ideas and discussion among my colleagues are some of the highlights. I felt like my opinions were respected from the day I interviewed here, and my contributions are valued and recognized. Communication is pretty good at many levels. I don't feel out of the loop about important decisions and changes (from my unit to university-wide). I work with a lot of smart people, and we have a freedom to try out new ideas. I have felt very supported in terms of professional growth: good training when I started, money for conferences and continuing education, and opportunities to take just about any class here that I want to through the Regents' scholarship.

The benefits are good although long-time Minnesotans might disagree; apparently they are not as good as they used to be, but they are far better than at universities where I worked previously. My teeth are happy that dental insurance costs are pretty low and affordable; that may be a function of the scale of this place. I like the programs the University has instituted in an effort to improve employee wellness (e.g., 100% health insurance coverage for preventative care like gyn exams, opportunities to take fitness classes, a farmer's market in the summer, coaching on changing health-related behaviors). They offer same-sex domestic partner benefits and are good at being inclusive throughout forms and other places where that information is relevant. I do feel that the administration is genuinely concerned with keeping employees happy and healthy even if I don't like every decision they make. 

The sheer size of the university means that it is something of a small city and has some really great resources; I can go to the dentist, doctor, pharmacy, post office, gym, a dance performance, register my car and get IT assistance on my personal laptop all without leaving campus. There are a lot of innovative projects going on technology-wise in many parts of the university as well as really interesting research in the academic departments. The location in an environmentally conscious (and, yes, very liberal) city that has a lot going on culturally and recreationally (for a smallish city) is another plus.
cons:
My experience with my colleagues is not the same University-wide. I know others who have had a less positive experience related to who their immediate co-workers are. Not everyone has a boss as communicative, respectful, and people-savvy as mine. I don't feel like I have many opportunities for advancement with the way my department/unit is structured which also means fewer opportunities for salary increases (not likely with current economic situation in Minnesota anyway). This isn't huge, but I don't like some of the tensions over/between the 4 different classifications of employees (faculty, professional & academic (P&A), civil service, and bargaining unit (represented by unions)); there is a little animosity (probably too strong a word but can't think of another) towards the faculty and, to a lesser degree, P&A staff at times from the other classes of employees. Winter in Minnesota is not great, but it's bearable.

The other negatives are more about academia in general. The University tends to operate as lots of little fiefdoms (departments, units, etc) where each unit or department or division does things their own way even if it duplicates something others on campus do. There may be some changes coming related to that, but that remains to be seen. As is probably not uncommon in large universities, there are many levels of bureaucracy which can slow down decisions and changes (e.g., hiring a new person for a faculty or professional position can take close to a year from posting the position to starting the job).

review_title: The good, the bad, and the ugly
pros: Free or reduced tuition, interesting learning experiences, opportunities to develop great friendships and build connections for later in your career.
cons: Awful pay unless you are management.... which it isn't hard to be management, as the U of M is notoriously top heavy. Also - be prepared as your work atmosphere will either be fantastic or absolutely awful and hostile.

review_title: Friendly, Supportive Environment.  May need clear goals regarding what you want to accomplish.
pros: People are generally friendly and helpful including the university bureaucracy.  Easily able to network.  Friendly work environment.  Supportive leadership.
cons: May need clear goals for what you need to do to advance your career.  Passive aggressive communication, also sometimes presenting as lack of communication, is sometimes an issue.

review_title: I t has been a learning experience.
pros: The University has several opportunities for professional growth.  There are mechanisms in place to ensure that the students are saavy about job searches and different career paths.
cons: There is not a lot of ethnic diversity in the student population and there is very little effort being made to entice the people of color in the communities that are in the immediate vacinity of the University.

review_title: A wonderful employer.  Every UMM student should consider finding a position within the school.
pros:
--Great accessibility for students
--Good opportunities for those with Federal Work Study financial assistance
--Many opportunities available in a variety of departments
--Warm, friendly staff
--Positions available both part-time during the school year and full-time during the summer.
--For the most part, facilities are excellent and modern, with good air conditioning and heating.
cons:
--May be difficult scheduling work around class schedule for some
--Wages are generally only minimum wage for students 
--May be difficult finding work experiences that will advance specific careers
--A small minority of facilities could stand significant refurbishment

review_title: U of M - Great Place for Professional Development
job_title: Communications and Program Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Ample opportunities for professional advancement and development. Vast opportunities to learn new skills and network. Good team environment with really cool, smart people.
cons: Because the organization is so large, there is a great deal of bureaucracy this can slow down projects and make it hard to make adjustments in real time to meet deadline.

review_title: Mediocrity is the norm, lots of opportunity to shine
pros: Tremendous diversity in students, staff, opportunities, type of positions available, the U has almost anything you could imagine.  When you work hear, you are helping to support the search for a cure to diabetes, of cancer, a way to feed the world, it is truly amazing
cons: Long term culture where mediocre performance is accepted, poor performance is awarded, and it takes forever to make any changes.

pros: The University of Minnesota allows personal and professional growth to those who take advantage of the opportunities offered.  There are offers of professional business classes as well as challenges to learn for everyone.
cons: Teaching is a lot of work and you have to understand that your wages aren't as competitive as they would be in the private sector.  Parking is expensive and not covered for part time employees.

pros: The staff at the University of Minnesota Recreation & Wellness center is awesome. Everyone gets along really well and works together fantastically. The trainers support each other and the team building weekend exercises are always a blast. Kevin Widmer is a great supervisor.
cons: There were a couple organizational issues that I know myself and several other people had when it came to finding client's records and attempting to record or process new information.

pros: Bookastore manages treat all of its employees with respect. The empower employees to take on more responsibility if needed, and are very open to new questions and ideas.
cons: You shouldn't expect very much in terms of pay there isn't a gradient of lateral movement. Sometimes things could be better explained in training. But what do you expect from a part time job

pros: Smart people, diverse computing environments, diverse styles of management, online access to the OED. Beautiful campus, good location, pretty good benefits. Often working conditions are in sparkling new buildings with the newest technology.
cons: Budgets can be tight, sometimes the red tape becomes overwhelming. The U is constantly trying to improve, which is good, but it also leads to a feeling of chaos and insecurity. Often working conditions are in old buildings with insufficient HVAC. They view IT as a place where budgets can be cut, and the workers are often vastly overworked.

job_title: Senior Research Fellow in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Challenged to perform the identical consulting duties as an Associate Professor with a PhD .
cons: Paid as an MS. Work "harder and faster" after 3 employees left and were not replaced. Publish or perish as an MS. Suggestion box had a camera pointed at it and a sign on it that said: "If you're not with us you're against us."

review_title: My experience as a researcher in University of Minnesota, Twin Cities My experience as a researcher in University of M
pros: The department has elite faculty panel and fantastic students providing a rich environment for research on state of the art methodology
cons: The weather in Minneapolis a big downside. Up to seven months of winter can be depressing at times. The weather in Minneapolis a big downside. Up to seven months of winter can be depressing at times.

pros: Much of the U is very supportive of continuing education, great benefits, competitive salary, fosters growth and promotes communication
cons: Some departments are harder to work for than others, the administrative union (AFSCME) is a joke and there is no way out unless you switch jobs - avoid a job sponsored by them if possible, as and admin expect to wear many hats including helping with HR and finance related things, finance at the U is hard to learn and varies per department.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistantship in the Aeropace Engineering and Mechanics Department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Great financial support gives you peace of mind and enables a comfortable lifestyle.
Excellent faculty, who are eager to engage with students, without any formalities.
A small department without bureaucracy  makes it easy to get things done.
cons: Department is small, and is forced to outsource many of the support functions that  experimenters and researchers may need. An example is the lack of trained technical staff on hand to help with projects, these need to be brought over from other departments if needed.

review_title: Positive experience working in staff position at University of Minnesota
job_title: Assistant Program Director in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
-Flexible work environment at the University
-Great benefits including vacation, retirement plan, healthcare benefits, tuition reduction
-Intelligent, passionate people all around you
cons:
-Academic environment can move slow so it takes a very long time to change
-Lack of innovation, universities are resistant to improve what doesn't work well
-Education sector has lower pay than private sector for staff positions

job_title: Graduate Student in Saint Paul, MN
pros: This is a great place to get a PhD in plant sciences. There is a huge risk reward, but as long as you understand what you are giving up by going to grad school you will be just fine.
cons: Work odd hours, work weekends, work on multiple different projects, high stress, uncertain future after graduation, experience multiple scientific failures over the course of 4-5 years.

pros: My colleagues all have a sense of pride for their work, which lends itself to a wonderful collaborative teamwork environment in which everyone is really pulling their weight and then some.  The benefits are a plus, as well.
cons: The University is a bit decentralized overall, so it can be difficult to know what kind of departmental culture you're going to encounter when moving within departments.

pros:
Excellent health care coverage.
Flexibility towards work & study.
Direct supervisors are very good.
Bureaucracy in my dept is not there. 
Easier to get things done within my dept. Electrical engineering
Funding opportunities for hard working studnets
cons:
Less pay.
no paid vacations.
senior management very opportunistic
whenever there is economic slowdown, the admin of the U puts the burden on clerical workers & graduate students.

review_title: Decent experience, a lot of hours
pros: It is a great starting point for anyone who is interested in working in Division I athletics. I was given a lot of responsibility and met leaders in my field in the Twin Cities area. I also know they offer great retirement benefits, though this was not a benefit given to graduate assistants.
cons: Extremely demanding hours and no Graduate Assistant union to fight this- I worked far, far more hours than the 20-hour "limit" for graduate assistants. Other Big Ten schools offer more competitive pay (ex. Iowa) and are less demanding.

review_title: Great Benefits, good work life balance, too many layers of management
pros: Though pay is a bit under average, the work life balance is great and you do get many benefits. Great place to use as a stepping stone to jump start your career.
cons: Too many layers of management, hard to really find the right person to talk to about concerns. Management doesn't make you feel like your opinion is really cherished.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: University of Minnesota, TC has a convenient location at Minneapolis. The campus looks nice and clean. And people are very friendly and helpful. The alumni network is very helpful as well.
cons: Although the university has an excellent reputation in Minnesota, it is not that effective to find a job out of the state. Relatively expensive compared to other mid west universities.

review_title: Gained a lot of hands on experience, but commuting can be annoying
job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Great experience. Gain exposure to many different research techniques and areas of research. Post-docs are very helpful, knowledgeable and approachable.
cons: If you do not live on or near campus, commuting can be a hassle. Even if you live on campus, the commuting during weekends can be a annoying since you often have to wait a long time for the bus. Often to get your foot in the door, you have to willing to perform tedious tasks

pros: There is a great scope for learning and growth at this academic institution. There are several state of the art technical facilities for experimental techniques in all fields, be it biomedical /pharmaceutical or engineering- based research. You can build an excellent network of contacts in the field of biomedical sciences/ pharmaceutical sciences as there are several excellent, extremely experienced faculty members whom you can easily reach out to at this university.
cons: There are no specific cons of working here, since you get fair employee benefits in terms of insurance and PTO.

pros: Great medical benefits. Great retirement program. Work for a Division 1 University. Most of the people are great.
cons: Supervisors, mostly incompetent.  Salary is not competitive. No teamwork, among departments/employees.  Backstabbing to get ahead. Toxic work environment. Keep your head down, do your job and still doesn't guarantee you'll keep your job. Do NOT value loyalty, dedication and years of service.

pros: It is a good place to start as a researcher in certain areas of Computer Science and Electrical Engineering. However, one must be careful in selecting an adviser, which can make or break your career goals when in Grad school.
cons: Management could be more considerate of Research Assistants who have to work crazy hours to meet deadlines, while being compensated at a rate that is among the lowest in the country.

review_title: Large university with SOME Academics/Scientists with even larger ego
pros: One of the largest  Universities in the Mid West, with great schools and colleagues, like the Colleague of Pharmacy, and School of Veterinary Medicine. It has very interesting research programs but progress and speed it is not a strength
cons: Like any large institution, politics is very strong. With exceptions, most of the research being done does not have a clear goal, but to generate data to renew the grant

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The university offers very flexible working hours. As a student researcher, there is also the potential for greater project independence than would be found in most conventional entry level jobs.
cons: Student workers are often not paid, paid through course credit, or paid lower wages than students working in industry (internships). The main impact of this is a lack of feeling of respect for ones time.

review_title: Not a great place to work unless you're faculty, even then I'm not so sure!
pros: Some great people and good benefits.
cons: Overall punitive, non-collaborative, highly political (office politics), managers not trained or held accountable, no clear advancement/career tracks.

review_title: Excellent place to work, but sliding
pros: Nearly paid tuition, great benefits, crazy amounts of vacation time, great coworkers, near transit, beautiful campus, focused on retention of employees
cons: Lack of funding, layoffs keep coming around, state support bleak, too much work not enough bodies, pay isn't at par with private sector, hiring pause, no raises for the foreseeable future (including COL), benefits slide every year

review_title: It is a very enriching experience to work with undergraduates and teaching them various aspects of chemistry.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The fact that you have to constantly answer various questions about chemistry keeps your knowledge preserved. It gives you an edge too, if you want to apply for a teaching position later in your career. The administration in the department is also very helpful and work together to provide a very productive environment.
cons: One challenge is to balance your teaching responsibilities with you own research because most of the teaching assistants are PhD candidates.

job_title: Athletic Fan Relations Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: It is a good job for people looking to get into collegiate athletics. The managers and job in general have many connections for college athletics. Many good people in the department  to work with.
cons: You are given a lot responsibility for pay. Not given nearly enough respect or credit for the duties preformed on a daily basis. Many other positions for student workers are paid better, but have half of the responsibility or stress.

pros: The University provides a high level of faculty autonomy and encourages staff to excel.  This is an institution that is on the leading edge in many fields.
cons: There tends to be some disconnect between field based staff and campus department leadership in some instances. They often mean well but are far removed from local customer needs within the context of the Land Grants outreach mission which can be a stress for greater MN Staff.

job_title: Multimedia Graphic Designer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great Benefits, good work life balance.
cons: Pay can be low depending on the unit and role. Keep in mind, your mileage may vary. It's a large organization with 26K+ employees. There is no way to review it and accurately rate the experience a prospective employee might have since it could be quite different depending on the unit and the person you report to. Also, your situation may also vary if you stay a long time. It has changed quite a bit since I first arrived.

pros: The University of Minnesota has great benefits and lots of jobs to pick from. If you are looking for a stable job, the U of MN is a good place to look.
cons: Red tape upon red tape to get anything done.  Additionally, promotions and salary increases are not dependent how how much work you do or how well you work, just who you hang out with.  Seems to be a problem across the board at the U of MN.

review_title: Great place for steady, stable employment; very limited opportunity for high achievers/climbers
pros: Great campus/work environment; good people; predictable & steady work; decent benefits; flexible & good work-life balance values; actively promotes/rewards health & wellness
cons: bureaucratic, limited opportunity for high level (internal) training for growth & development, non-competitive pay, faculty-run administration keeps the U behind the times in business practices

job_title: Senior Innovation Fellow in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Freedom, lack of structure, ability to pursue projects and work that you find interesting.  Great connectivity to investors, doctors, and key opinion leaders - a great place to spend a year, grow, and network.
cons: Salary, no direct conduit into funding and cash - potential to cloud the innovation process with external collaborations that are difficult to navigate away from

review_title: Good school with decent staff support
pros: 75% tuition benefit and good health insurance.  Environment can vary depending on area but generally management is caring and competent.  Staff movement within the school is common and can be a good option if mobility in a specific area is limited.
cons: Salaries haven't really increased in years and depend on union negotiations so it can put managers in a tough position in terms of hiring and raises since, to a large degree, they don't have control over what they can offer.

review_title: Great job, but my specific experience may not be representative
pros:
Independent workplace with little micromanagement.
Brilliant, successful colleagues who are a pleasure to work with. 
Flexible work schedule.
Fantastic benefits. 
Competitive salary.
cons:
I am the youngest employee at my level in the division by at least 20 years.
Being such a large university, it often can seem as if you're inside your own little bubble separate from the rest of the university. 
Parking is expensive and rigid (i.e. cannot get a permit only for winter).

review_title: If you can find a good pocket, it's the best.
pros: Amazing benefits, able to work and support content tied to teaching, research, and outreach. Feel like what I do really helps build bridges and make a difference.
cons: Huge bureaucracy that can be tough to navigate. Pay can't keep up with private sector. Environment can be hugely different depending on what department you're in.

pros:
- There are some lovely, dedicated, nerdy staff to work with
- Teaching the kiddos and teens is fulfilling and fun (most days!)
-  If there is free time, you sometimes get to help on some fun projects
cons:
- Lots of turnover (people feel overworked and not supported)
- There isn't enough capacity to allow for managerial staff to best support their staff
- No health benefits (They keep you just under the 75% mark) 
- Opportunities for growth are slim 
- Not much transparency
- UMN bureaucracy is unavoidable

review_title: Huge academic institution where some of the little branches start to dry up
pros: Benefits, benefits, benefits! Heady academic environment with a lot of interesting and well... academic minds around you.
cons: One can easily feel small and kind of lost at such a massive institution. Rules and guidelines, like most huge institutions, are strictly observed and enforced. Not much room for creative bending of the rules to accommodate circumstances.

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: It has a strong interdisciplinary PhD program on novel sensor research and development. Also the advisers are professional and helpful with strong academic abilities.
cons: The winter is cold, and the temperature difference is huge that some people may not get used to it.  As an university in a city, the rent is pretty high.

review_title: Lots of Opportunity at The U of M
job_title: Grad Student Researcher in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I think Minnesota culture is prevalent at the University. Minnesotans tend not to be flashy and tend to be reserved but friendly. Huge university with tons of resources no matter what direction you take as a grad student.  Minneapolis is a great place to live as well. Highly recommended.
cons: I think you have to take initiative in finding a path to turning your education into a career.  The more time it takes to do this, the harder it is.

pros:
Flexible hours
Independent research
Laid-back environment
Collaborative work
Opportunities to present and discuss work
Excellent characterization facilities
Excellent benefits
cons:
The pay is lower than if working for industry
Some days can be boring (this is experimental research)
This is a very big university and so sometimes can lose the importance of work

review_title: University of Minnesota is what you make of it.
pros: If you can find a unit that is less pron to financial downturns (Law, Medical, Business) and take advantage of furthering your education it is a great place to work.
cons: There is very little turnover and which makes it difficult to get a high paying job unless you move from department to department every couple of years. Jobs positions and pay are very regimented.

review_title: Cutting Edge research, with a few downsides.
pros:
Worked in a highly funded lab which gave access to cutting edge technology in my field. 
Satisfaction of knowing your work can provide positive results for patients.
Benefits package was competitive.
Floating holidays.
cons:
Politics of working in a large lab. 
Management of ideas and personalities was often ignored. 
Some managers were difficult to work with.
Lonely at times as most lab jobs tend to be. 
Scholarship reimbursement for higher education has been substantially reduced.

review_title: Tough Transition from Private to Public Sector
job_title: Senior Professional and Administrative (P&A) Role in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Casual yet Professional Environment, Tuition benefit (IF you decide to take classes), ripe with potential, great opportunity to learn in a super-complex organization, I don't take work home with me
cons: Lots of red tape  and "checks and balances" to get things done, low autonomy of work, budget-focused (no long-term vision), over-abundance of non-value added work, below-market salary, no clear career path

review_title: Worked first as a student worker, then was hired on as a staff member.
job_title: Principal Accounts Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The medical and leave benefits are amazing. It's hard to find a company that provides 4 weeks of vacation right off the bat. A lot of people there also have good job satisfaction and stability.
cons: Lower salary (due to insane benefits). Rigid promotion process (not really merit based). Hierarchy is complex and difficult to navigate.

pros: Pretty good benefits. More vacation and sick leave than most employers, so the work/life balance is very good. Sense that you are a part of something important and valuable.
cons: Salaries are very low compared to market rates. Many departments are still very hierarchical and do not partner with other departments, even when it would make business/financial sense to do so. Ingrained sense of hierarchy can also prevent real innovation.

pros: Supervisors really care about their employees, they once bought me my favorite candy because they knew I was having a terrible day. They embraced constructive criticism and often expected helpful feedback during team meetings. Employer was willing to work with my schedule and made hours flexible.
cons: Honestly, not many complaints. Maybe having more options to grow into higher positions.

review_title: fairly good, but kind of boring
pros: It's a good place, lots of good ideas and motivated people,  you get experience in lab and it's a good way to build your resume.
cons: but there's not too much opportunity to get out and do something important. You usually just do what the PI wants you to do and don't get much time to design your own projects.

review_title: U of M is a good choice for people looking for steady job without higher pay.
job_title: Junior Applications Developer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Many resources are available to school employees.  The school is near the downtown with convenient traffic. If you are interested in research area, there are plenty of opportunities.
cons: Unless you are working with research related area, daily job is kind of boring. Have to communicate with students who are not actually professionals.

pros: Land grant institution with an emphasis on research. Beautiful Twin Cities campus with ongoing capital projects.
cons: Difficult to advance from administrative to professional or managerial opportunities. Tendency to hire from the outside for those positions rather than to promote from within. The culture is quite cliquey, and passive/aggressive.

pros: Closer to where I was around and less time wasted on traveling, so maybe per hour of work and travel due to work, I maybe making more than I thought
cons: Not too much exciting opportunities. Most people are a bit more lay back. It's one of the cons for me since I like to get things done quicker, but could be a pros for others

job_title: Community Program Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
As a research coordinator, I had a lot of flexibility in my position. I enjoyed the atmosphere, which was laid-back, yet intellectually stimulating. I was able to gain great experience in this position and was given a lot of independence and responsibility.

The benefits are great.
cons: Salary is on the low-end and there are not a lot of opportunities for advancement.

pros: Very customer oriented. Large focus on employee well being and development. Constantly working to improve quality of the service they provide.
cons: Some disconnect between central department and individual building staffs. Policy changes happen somewhat frequently. Compensation unequal depending on building you work in.

review_title: Required clerical union membership in AFSCME. Pay is based on steps/seniority. Nothing is merit based.
pros: Great benefits: medical, dental, state retirement plan, free tuition, practically impossible to get fired from a union job.
cons: Union is rife with lazy slackers. Those who are competent and hard working pick up their slackers with no reward. No incentive for good work except for own self worth, which leads to resentment and bitterness.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Flexible hours, short shifts, great supervisors who really care about you, great training and learning opportunities. They know that you will be moving on eventually, so they try to train you for other positions after graduation.
cons: Some coworkers don't take the jobs seriously. The money wasn't great for the work we were doing, but it was a convenient job for campus.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Worked here as a teaching assistant in the humanities for four years. Health benefits were good.
cons: Pay was atrociously bad compared to grad assistants in the STEM fields (Science, Technology, Engineering and Medicine). Every six years or so, an effort to unionize graduate assistants is sponsored by a major union. The University pays millions of dollars to an alumnae-founded labor-law-firm to bust each union drive.

pros: Good health insurance, and decent salary for recent grad. There are opportunities to learn new things.
cons: Micromanagement and no room to grow professionally. Creativity and individuality is frowned upon.

pros: great healthcare benefits, good retirement benefits, easy commute via public transit, financial support for employee education, flexible vacation, investing/financial planning education for staff/faculty
cons: monotonous, bureaucratic environment that often leads to gross inefficiencies in how tasks are completed, entrenched staff members who refuse to grow as employees & continue to perpetuate outmoded ways of doing things

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: No really, the benefits were the only reason I stayed. I guess there are some positives when it comes to advising, but it's really hit or miss and a little too hit or miss for my liking.
cons: classic minnesota passive aggressiveness. The union busting efforts were a real downer and really took the wind out of everyone's sails, I feel. International students are often put in a position where they suffer from a two-tiered system of graduate appointments because of work visa issues.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Solid health benefits. Possibility for housing. As long as things got done, I had lots of flexibility in my job. Very friendly and collaborative environment. All the benefits you would expect at a large university - many interesting seminars, speakers and events.
cons: With the exception of top leadership, tenured professors and sport coaches, the salary is what you would expect from an university employer - low.  The UMN Saint Paul campus is slow and lack dining options.

pros: My research assistant position was split between a few professors.  The work was interesting and engaging, ranging from technical energy simulations to guiding students.
cons: The flexible schedule was, at times, too inconsistent.  Many of the tasks were fairly last minute requests, which doesn't always jive with an already busy class schedule.

review_title: Great Benefits - Lack of Challengin Work
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Benefits are great, campus is beautiful. Lots of opportunity to work in different areas and learn due to it being a public research university.
cons: Wasteful spending. Saw a lot of employee waste since its pretty difficult to get let go. The work for software development was not challenging. Think "more financial reports."

pros:
+ Academic environment - people around you are intellectual and engaged in interesting work
+ Casual attire (in most positions)
+ Urban envrionment, accessible by public transit
+ Excellent benefits
cons: Administration seems to be a bit of a mess, especially in the Academic Health Center. Incompetent or absent leadership leads to competitive and unproductive relationships between peers.

job_title: Student Event Staff in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The culture at McNamara is wonderful. Although I did not work there full time and was a student at the time, I still felt like I was a big part of the team and making an impact on the events taking place in the venue.  Great experience to enter the event world!
cons: The shifts can be long hours but if you want to be in the event world that is part of the work.

review_title: Great place to learn a lot of experience
pros: Great environment plenty of resources for help and education. Work life balance is very achievable and there are plenty of opportunities to grow.
cons: Things can take a long time to change. Reward for hard work is sometimes limited the way reviews for each department only allow for limited amount of outstanding achievers per group.

pros: Great benefits, if you like being in an academic environment that's a plus too.  The PTO is pretty generous and flexible, I have a great direct supervisor.
cons: It feels like potential is wasted and I know I'd never get promoted unless I stuck around for 30+ years, the pay is absolutely terrible.

review_title: The benefits are outstanding, but very little structure to advancement opportunities.
job_title: Associate to Director in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Benefits package far out paces the private sector, especially for retirement.
cons: Salaries are stagnant and raises, even cost of living, are far and few in between. Most employees were on a hiring freeze the past 4 years, with the exception of upper managers who gave themselves raises (fact checking completed).

pros: Exciting, interesting work with smart people.  I get to be involved with cutting edge research and am afforded lots of freedom to pursue my own interests, although this probably varies a lot between research groups.
cons: There is an excessively bureaucratic culture combined with extreme decentralization, which makes getting accurate answers about benefits, standards etc extremely difficult.  Benefits have changed arbitrarily and for bad reasons.  The University provides almost no institutional support for postdoctoral researchers, for example career development services.

review_title: We need more equality and equal opportunities in every department at the U of M
pros: Excellent CME benefits and sick leave.
cons: Lack of ethnic diversity faculty and professional staff; cliques; hierarchy and preferential treatment.

review_title: I learned a lot and was charmed by Minneapolis
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Innovation and a bright future. The location near the core of a vibrant city enhances the experience immensely and helps keep even harried graduate students centered. In CEMS the compensation was good (for grad school).
cons: The usual cons associated with grad school life. Living in the city is not as cheap as in the farm fields near other midwestern universities, but I'm ok with that.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: If you do research for a professor at the University of Minnesota, you will benefit from the knowledge and experience of excellent, leading researchers in their fields.  Positives include access to neat labs and equipment and plentiful opportunities for personal growth, learning, and development. Of course, work schedules are tailored around classes, which is also hugely helpful for busy students.
cons: Some of the lab equipment is aged. Other than that, no 'cons' I can think of!

job_title: Project Program Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: autonomy, good health benefits, interesting work
cons: There are no clearly followed career path(s) for employees.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Good people to work with, Very kinda and considerate
Great Advisors, Very knowledgeable and helpful, but sometimes hard to get a hold of
 Amazing benefits, the Health and Dental are great, and you get payed for your educations
Flexible Schedule, work when you want, just make sure you are committed to getting the word done on a regular basis
cons:
Long hours, sometimes working more then 40hrs a week 
Pressure to get result
Fairly low salary, but compensated by benefits and education

review_title: The University of Minnesota is a great place to work
pros:
Metro transportation options are very good.
Graduate Student stipend and benefits are very competitive and fair.
The environment is very collaborative and friendly.
The graduate program in neuroscience is very progressive and offers many opportunities for networking and career advancement.
cons: The University of Minnesota does not yet get the recognition it deserves.

review_title: Good place to work depending on your supervisor
pros:
They had free tuition for employees, now you pay a portion.
I had great benefits in my position. 
Their training for accounting staff is very thorough.
cons:
They had free tuition for employees, now you pay a portion. 
They reduced benefits in some positions due to state budget cuts.
There is no help for you if your supervisor is a tenured faculty, no matter how awful they are.

review_title: University of Minnesota: Great facilities, mediocre funding management.
pros: Great work life balance and benefits package. Excellent researcher opportunities and great level of autonomy. Amazing resources for nanotech fabrication and characterization.
cons: Siloing of funds in colleges inhibit some cross disciplinary research opportunities. This creates situations where one can apply for funding in a related area, but not receive (or even be considered) because it is viewed as another college's "turf".

pros: It is a very good experience, mainly because my department is great. They really want you to get your degree, and they provide a top tier education and degree. Health plan is very good and subsidized by department. Teaching load is very reasonable and they provide great resources to support your teaching.
cons: Overall it is a good environment. Commuting by car can be difficult however, and the dependent health coverage is expensive. Also there is no dental.

pros: Intellectually stimulating environment due to high concentration of top quality frontier research in science and engineering. Strong community feel. The University is ethos good. Typically good health benefits. Good transport links to surrounding areas, including free connector bus services to other campuses. Twin-Cities are a great place to live and work.
cons: Long working hours are often required, though this is not unusual in academic research environments and is very much dependent on the nature one's research.

job_title: Member Service Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: flexible and fun environment. great coworkers and supervisors. free membership if not full time student.
cons: minimum wage. lowest paying department on campus. Unorganized and inexperienced coworkers when they actually did their job, that is.  strict rules from upper management.

job_title: Honors Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The biggest pros of this position involve both flexibility of work around your regular student schedule, and work that is highly thought-provoking and rewarding. You do get to work with reputable professors and learn every step of the way.
cons: Not applicable. Wouldn't really change a thing, other than assigning work that can be done in a given timespan, but I think that's all dependent on the professor involved and is really on the assistant's responsibility.

pros: The University has their training down to a science. After completing the training for access to their financial system, I felt very confident with my ability to do my job. The job environment was also laid back and pleasant.
cons: There wasn't a clear path for upward mobility for me. I felt like if I wanted to get more experience in my field I would have apply outside of the U of M.

review_title: Not what I thought it would or could be
pros:
The benefits are solid and reasonably priced. 
Great lively campus atmosphere, especially in the Spring.
The retirement package is second to none (they contributure 10.5%).
cons:
Individuals works in silos = No team collaboration/atmosphere.
Lack of any formal (or even informal) training programs.
Little compensation for the amount of expected work and raises every 5 years, if that.
Heirarchy and beauracracy breeds a "Yes, sir...anytime sir" kind of environment (if you question authority your days are numbered).

review_title: Money isn't spread out evenly, but if your interests line up you are golden.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great staff and quality professors
cons: Not all projects and professors have money to spare.  Finding a quality position is hard, but if you are diligent you can land a position.  If you are not interested in a funded project I urge you to reconsider.

pros: A good resume building experience. As a student-worker, I was able to gain office experience to help me get an administrative job upon graduation. In many ways, it is still the job in which I had the most responsibility resting on me.
cons: The downside of being a student worker is that you are a low-wage alternative to what would otherwise be a full-time benefits position for someone else. And after you graduate, your employment is over.

review_title: I've been working in my current job at the U of M for a year now.
job_title: Lab Technician in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Scheduling is usually really flexible for undergraduate positions. You usually have a good amount of freedom and independence with work. I've had really friendly co-workers in my experience.
cons: The pay isn't the best, but academia is notorious for that anyway, and compensation can vary from department to department.

review_title: I developed a lot of pride for my job and the school.
pros: Great people. The office environment is centered around success for the school.  Everyone is very friendly and willing to help everyone out.  The workload was never too bad and being in sports was always very interesting.
cons: It is very difficult to climb the ranks and get a promotion.  Not many positions became available so I was never able to get a promotion.

review_title: Little fish in a big pond
pros: Employees have access to great benefits and are generally well compensated. There is a lot of independence in the workplace in most cases.
cons: Management is poorly regulated. There are not 360-degree reviews and the university is a typical academic tenure environment - which means that just because people are good researchers, it doesn't mean they are good managers.

review_title: Excellent place to get trained , to gain knowledge
job_title: Graduate Student in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
Hi All,
I got trained with TecTist in the month of November 2015 and got placed in 2016.It was really an excellent training provided by the trainers and hope  every one gets trained here by not wasting your time in referring to some other Training companies.I am so thankful to all the management in getting me a Job.
Thanks
cons: would like to refer all my frndz

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Friendly people, flexible working hours. Good exposure to interesting research, plenty of opportunities.
cons: Large campus makes collaboration with other departments difficult and time consuming. Bureaucracy at the U is intense and there are always hoops to jump through, especially when doing human research.

pros: Lots of opportunity to network if you are motivated and open your own doors.
cons: It's hard to review the entire organization from a research position because my experience is completely driven by the environment of the lab I work for. That is bad as often as it's good. There are efforts underway to create more support and communication for professional employees, but they are quite slow. My experience has been sadly isolating despite the size of the organization.

pros: very friendly and relaxed atmosphere within my smaller department and research team. tuition benefit if you choose to take classes. I completed my masters in 2.5 years paying out of pocket.
cons: work load comes in waves, could spend a long time between research projects really scrounging to find tasks. lots of slow moving employees and procedures.

pros: Flexible scheduling and decent pay for a fairly easy job
cons: The closing shifts include cleaning the entire facility by yourself which takes forever. Often, you are there til 1am depending on how long people are playing for that night.

pros: Smart, compassionate and gifted Colleagues
cons: Burden of upper level administration, level of politics, no decisions are made and lack of progress. Faculty driven decision making, who are rarely involved in how things actually operate or function

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: great facilities, PIs, program, good benefits, competitive pay for grad students.
cons: Too much overhead consumes the majority of research funding. The U is actually better than most other universities; this is a broad problem shared with most research universities.

pros: Flexible scheduling. Most people you work with are great. My team was awesome and  I learned a lot from the Full Time Employees
cons: Once you start interacting with higher level employees you see why no significant or relevant changes get made. A lot of bureaucracy and back scratching.

job_title: IT Manager I in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The work is very diverse and you can be as engaged as you want. In the IT field, you can work for central IT (OIT - Office of Information Technology), college level IT, or unit-level IT. Each one has its own advantages, different sets of politics, and different levels of autonomy.
cons: Politics as always, but more than that, large egos from the faculty can get in the way of getting work done.

pros: Great benefits, flexible hours, many great people.  I thought it was a great place to work for a long period of time.
cons: It is a very political environment, some very nasty people are allowed to get ahead.  There is no such thing as job security.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Vancouver, BC
pros: The UofM Twin Cities campus is beautiful, though it is extremely big! I felt very well compensated as a graduate student there. The pay was fair and considering I also received tuition, it was really good! The medical plan for graduate students is also fantastic.
cons: There is a lot of formal procedural processes that can be confusing and annoying, plus they frequently change. Makes it feel hard to be well informed.

pros: I found a summer research position and loved it. I worked with the heads of departments, met with them weekly, and submitted a paper for publication by the end.
cons: I was probably paid the minimum amount possible for my work and wish I had had more frequent in person contact with my team.

pros: There's a diversified group of brilliant individuals working at the cutting edge of their field and bringing others up with them.
cons: It's antiquated technologically speaking, and not all of the programs are forward looking.  My program is based more on the past than the future.

review_title: Great place to work - friendly staff, but a lot of bureaucracy
pros: Great campus, lively group of employees, and tons to do around the Twin Cities area. Cost of living is relatively low as well. People are generally helpful, whether it be IT or other departments. Fun/easy going atmosphere.
cons: Parking is bad and HR could use some work.

review_title: Housing & Residential Life at the University of Minnesota
pros:
-Flexible student jobs 
-Emphasis on personal and professional development
-Most supervisors are very kind and genuinely interested in you as a person (not just an employee)
cons:
-Sometimes there's a lack of consistency between different residential halls supervision
-It can be challenging for more conservative individuals to hold their beliefs in such a liberal department.

pros:
Location: easy to commute to, and reasonable price of living in Minneapolis.
Health benefits: health and dental insurance for employee and spouse / domestic partner.
cons:
No growth opportunities within UMN, and the university rating is average in academic world.
Compensation is below average in comparison with other universities.
Little to no mentoring from principal investigators.

review_title: Way too many levels of management
pros: Very good benefits and cost of benfits. Lots of people take lots of time off because of the academic calendar. Pace is luxurious compared to corporate world.
cons: Cronyism. Union signs over final decisions in HR disputes.- to HR! Academic elitism.

review_title: Short Take On University Student Jobs
pros: The University does very well in teaching its students and junior employees how to think critically, and prepare them for careers in the future.
cons: Working for the University can be a roller-coaster, sometimes you end up working for great people and other times it is very difficult to find common ground. This is in part because of its diverse culture and constantly changing graduates that hire student workers.

pros: Work is flexible in hours as long as you get work completed. Coworkers genuinely interested in building a community.
cons: Expect to be frustrated with incompetence in senior management. Compensation is strongly tied to seniority and not much else.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Relatively good benefits compared to other jobs.
cons: low salaries, confusing leadership, confusing and often unpleasant HR. For post doctoral associates in science, I found the university does not do much to improve the current poor working conditions (low salaries, expected over time), but I suppose that would also depend on the PI involved.

job_title: Student Administrative Support in Minneapolis, MN
pros: My coworkers and the people I met while working have definitely been the high point of the job. They are friendly, helpful, and don't have a problem getting you up to speed with your work.
cons: It can take some time to settle in. The University is a big organization with lots of moving parts. It can be intimidating to enter into, so be prepared to hit the ground running.

review_title: Friendly and non competitive environment to work as a Research Coordinator
pros: Flexible hours, Great learning environment and ability to function independently. There are opportunities for employees to further develop their careers through  the Regent's scholarship program.
cons: Salary scale is poor. No sound metrics to benchmark employee performance and little incentive or opportunities to be a stand-out performer in the work place.

pros: The work life balance and benefits are great. Most managers are quite flexible. There are some extremely talented and smart individuals. Some exciting projects taking place.
cons: There are very few opportunities for growth into leadership roles beyond project and product management. Management is inconsistent and not very flexible in methods.

pros: Great organization. There is plenty of room for growth, and plenty of degrees to pursue with the employee tuition benefit.
cons: Can be hard to break into; salaries are typical of higher education, and tend to be lower than private positions.

review_title: Great place to be a grad student
pros:
The Graduate Student Health Plan is amazing -- it includes vision and dental, and I've never had to pay more than a $10 copay for anything, including medications and an IUD.
As a grad student, the hours are very flexible.
cons: Grad students are paid much less than they deserve; it's not uncommon for Ph.D. students to quit after getting their Masters to pursue a higher-paying job elsewhere.

review_title: Low-pay but great experience and cheap tuition through regents scholarship
pros: An excellent opportunity to learn state of the art molecular biology techniques, work at the frontlines of vaccinology, and develop close relationships with PI/post-docs. Also great academic scholarship for full-time employees- the regent's scholarship covers 75% of the cost of a course, each term. Finally, two weeks of paid vacation.
cons:
Low pay 
Bureaucracy 
Academia is annoying, but I guess that depends on you POV.

pros: Great pay and benefits, lots of vacation time. Also, there is a lot of workplace pride at the U.
cons: There is always a lot of pressure to downsize departments and cut costs. There is also a culture that is status-conscious based on one's place in the hierarchy of the U staff.

review_title: Probably the best job I have ever had.
pros:
Good benefits.
Great people to work for and with.
Stable company has been in existence for app: 190 years and will be there for another.
cons:
Very liberal. The feelings or demeanor that comes across. Higher institution attitude is not the same as it is in the real world.
Big organization.
The new President was hired to do exactly what he is doing.

review_title: My employers used my position to train me for the real world workforce.
pros: They know you can't be retained indefinitely, so they will not try to trap you in a go-nowhere job for decades. They pay reasonably. It is an overall uniform payment system. They must make accommodations for students' academic demands.
cons: There can be a lot of supervisor turnover in some departments leaving a person in trouble if looking for references.`

review_title: Provides valuable job experience for student workers, along with flexibility for class schedules
pros: Flexibility of schedule, which is great if you are a student with and gives you the ability to have a second job if you need it.
cons: Salary level isn't always comparable to the amount of training you've had in comparison to other student jobs on campus; it really depends on which department you're in and how much funding they have

job_title: Student Accounting Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Flexible hours while taking classes at the University. Great being able to work while going to school and not have to commute to a job.
cons: Not really any opportunities for advancing while a student working. Work tasks are often repetitive and not very engaging.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Lab experience, outdoor work, learned research methods, could work when I had free time (helpful for working while in school)
cons: Tedious lab work and tasks, work dependent on weather, not a standard 9-5 job in the summer when planting

job_title: Executive Project Coordinator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The benefits are good working for a state organization, and the reduced cost education opportunities invaluable if you choose to take advantage of them.
cons: I found that the opportunities for advancement were minimal and rigidity surround the hours was challenging.

pros: The U of M was a terrific place to work that offered daily challenges and the opportunity for advancement. Plus amazing benefits.
cons: Sometimes you will be in a small division so you will need to know how to prioritize and not feel overwhelmed.

review_title: Be selective and do research about the department you work for!
job_title: Community Programs Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent benefits program in terms of vacation and sick time.
cons:
Low pay compared to private market
Few opportunities to move up based on merit-- you have to know somebody who knows somebody.
Require Master's and  Ph.D. to move up at the University, but then remove that benefit from employees creating stagnation.

review_title: It takes up most of my life, but it is very interesting.
pros:
You can work with the best scientists.
They have great research facilities.
There is a lot of room for career growth.
cons:
There is not as great pay or benefits as a biomedical company would have.
My job take up most of my life.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Great neural engineering and tissue engineering groups. 
Tight knit graduate students.
Professors who are approachable and helpful.
Overall an engaging group who want to help you succeed.
cons: Not very many resources for moving on to a career outside of academic research. The University has a career center (as do most large universities), but the PIs themselves aren't a ton of help when it comes to helping students find careers.

review_title: I've had a good experience at the University of Minnesota, although this depends strongly on your department/supervisor.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Well-organized administration, friendly people, the university is health-conscious (encourages cycling to work, etc, and rewards you for doing this), extra benefits like cheaper car-rentals via the university even for private use
cons: Cold weather, some analytical facilities could be better, very poor dining option on/around campus, at least in my department the offices are horrible

review_title: Problems of a public university and budget stress
pros: I'm happy as a staff member working here, supporting faculty, graduate students, and undergrads.  The atmosphere is very mission focused and people want to be nice on a personal level.
cons: Budget cuts and crises make moving forward and up hard. There is no commitment to loyalty or development within departments (unless it is internally driven) and moving on to other jobs is usual.

review_title: University of MN is a top ranked research and teaching institution in a major urban setting
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Faculty research to improve lives and make a difference in communities; good opportunity for professional development and personal growth, excellent benefits.
cons: University is a big place, not as many promotions available, many people stay in their jobs for long time.

job_title: Usability Lab Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Provides a lot of learning opportunities for students trying to get valuable real-world experience, especially if it's within your field.
cons: Some of the jobs can be monotonous. However, being a student worker doesn't provide a whole lot of dynamic activity.

review_title: Great place to work with multiple opportunities
job_title: Research and Media Manager in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Many opportunities to grow and learn. Flexible work arrangements available. Good benefits including ample sick/vacation time. Ability to work autonomously and without micromanagement. Surrounded by innovation and access to great minds.
cons: Lower wages than private sector. Red tape sometimes gets in the way of efficiency.

pros: Intellectually stimulating, encouraged educational growth, allowed time for school prioritization,
cons: The only real con of my position was that I worked independently a lot of the time, and I prefer to work with others at least sometimes.

pros: actual work hours per week as a TA are consistent with expectations outlined by faculty and previous TAs
cons: the course you are assigned to teach can change significantly between the fall and spring semesters.
