For example, one spring I taught introductory electricity and magnetism to first and second year undergraduate students, then the subsequent fall semester I taught quantum mechanics to first year physics PhD students.

review_title: The U of MN is a collection of organizations...some are great, avoid others.  In particular, avoid OIT.
pros: Very stable employer, looks great on resume, everyone knows the U.
cons: Below market pay, bureaucracy, politics, and central IT in particular has a poor culture created by entrenched long term employees, second string middle managers, and years of poor leadership and problems.

review_title: Good biotechnology programs, I assume work is different in each lab.
pros: As a grad student, having funding is key. I think working at UMN as a full time faculty could be good too if you are interested in that path. Strong research. I had a lot of freedom.
cons: I had little direction (but that is likely very lab specific). The culture at UMN is kind (not cutthroat) but also not very open.

pros: Nice benefits, big organization, lots of different equipment and solutions to learn. Depending on your request they will provide with Windows laptop or Apple. $10000 a year tuition help.
cons: Low start salary. Not flexible with salary increase. Everybody gets same increase. No appreciation for extra time, no overtime pay.

pros: The university has a friendly student body, flexible work  and the bosses are good and fair in their assessment of the employees.
cons: The climate is harsh and the work can get quite lonely. The job can be demanding depending on the deliverable's expected of you.

pros: Flexibility with class schedule. Interest in growing students personally and professionally for future. Shifts were as short or as long as needed and they allowed studying when there weren't big projects to work on.
cons: The pay was low and there were often tedious projects to do that didn't seem to have much end value. The supervisors were bored and spent a lot of time looking over your shoulder.

pros: You get to become a Union Member and gain seniority throughout, one free meal a day, some delicious meals.
cons: Managed by Aramark and its a little oppressive because of that, recipes aren't always thought through and sometimes include things in ridiculous proportions, depending on manager of area there is great potential for bad morale.

review_title: The good and bad are about equal here
job_title: End User Support in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great environment to work in, lots of diversity.  People are pleasant and the atmosphere is very inclusive.
cons: Professional development can sometimes be few and far between.  No opportunities for over-time.  Raises more than 3% of salary are impossible to get.

pros: Good benefits and competitive pay. Beautiful campus. Friendly co-workers.
cons: Disrespected by many of the faculty, often felt like a hierarchy. Not as much opportunities for advancement. Tuition hikes have become an issue over the years and it's becoming increasingly harder to afford going to the U of MN.

review_title: Loved working here, great environment and people.
job_title: Interlibrary Loan Assistant in Morris, MN
pros: It's a library, so it's quiet, but not usually library-quiet, like public libraries. I worked in Interlibrary Loan and I loved that job. The library staff also throws a party for the students at the end of every semester, with little gift bags.
cons: None that I can think of except typical student job wages, but that's expected.

pros: Flexible hours that work around your academic schedule. Most jobs are fairly close to campus making it ideal for students that live on campus.
cons: It is fairly easy to feel lost in a large organization such as the University of Minnesota as an entry level employee. Most student jobs are not very motivating.

pros: Opportunities to jump around to different positions/departments.  Great work/life balance.  Low pressure. A ton of opportunities to advance your learning - always interesting seminars happening.  Use the regent's scholarship to receive a huge discount on tuition. Benefits are great!
cons: Slow pace.  Raises are nearly impossible for administrative staff beyond the 2-3% annual bump.  Processes can feel archaic.

review_title: U of Minnesota - Bureaucracy at the peak.
pros:
good benefits
good place to learn and educate
cons:
Very poor communication between management and staff,
Promotions, and overall employment based on seniority NOT on your performance. This is why 
more people are not willing to bring new ideas and more focus on maintaining the status-quo.

review_title: Professional, friendly environment with helpful, active coworkers. The professional environment helps me stay motivated.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The coworkers at the University of Minnesota are helpful and productive. They help me be more productive. I love the atmosphere.
cons: Parking at the University of Minnesota is a hassle. Public transit is decent, but if I need to drive to school, it is very difficult to get a parking place.

pros: Work with students, active environment during summer months and relaxing environment during the year, job can be both challenging and easy at times, get to work with great people, understand you are a student first and are okay with being flexible,
cons: Only a student position, cannot move up the ladder, sometimes the work you do doesn't feel rewarding (scanning documents, making copies, cleaning, those kind of things).

pros: People are good to work, everybody carried there own weight, The customers were great. Wonderful pay and benefits.
cons: Hours were a bit tough, Commute was very long, upper management wasn't the best I have worked with.

pros: Work outside, got lots of exercise to keep off the college lbs. decent pay and flexible to class schedule.  understood class came first.  Can learn some decent machine/horticulture skills/building skills if you are in the right unit.
cons: Winters can be tough.  Snow emergency call-in very early on very rare occasions.  Can't be afraid of a little hard work.

pros: There are always a variety of positions to choose from. They pay undergraduate workers very well compared to a lot of private institutions. Coworkers will take you seriously even though you're a student. Your overall success is what is most important, so they're very flexible when it comes to balancing academics and work.
cons: Positions can be competitive. Communication can be spotty between higher-ups and supervisors.

pros:
Very welcoming campus and office environment 
Interesting and applicable work done on Scholars walk
Excellent networking opportunity 
Excellent flexibility in hours
cons:
It could get repetitive and tedious.
It was not very challenging
Limited available hours because of a large number of student employees.
Work-Study dependent employment

pros: They offer a good benefit package, the best thing about it is the great health insurance!I also like the  positive work environment.
cons: sometimes merit does not matter, and the work load distribution is not even. some of the supervisors don't treat people with respect

pros: Lots of opportunities to meet and collaborate with professionals that are at the cutting-edge with their respective technologies. However, pay is moderate to low.
cons: Pay is moderate to low and the University is a giant bureaucracy. It is impossible to make things happen quickly.

pros: Benefits, flexibility, compensation, tuition benefits, wonderful faculty colleagues, some areas really push for innovation and continuous improvement
cons: Location (urban), parking (expensive), traffic, layers of classified staff and managers--lots of staff people stay in organization too long without understanding the pressures of the outside world.

pros: The research job I am working in has a lot of room for job growth/ expansion. There are many opportunities for new experiences and responsibilities. And the people are great to work with!
cons: In the lab, a large requirement of time is dedicated to working on weeknights and weekends. The compensation doesn't really amount to total hours worked or time put in, in comparison.

review_title: Worked in a research facility doing manufacturing and job met typical expectations.
pros:
Very flexible in scheduling.
Can work small hours if a student and then get more on weekends if desired.
cons:
Movement as a student worker is minimal.
Some things occur slowly because of all of the procedures that need to be performed.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: With tuition covered, healthcare covered (the best healthcare ever!), and being well paid on top of it all, the U pays its GRA's incredibly well.
cons: It can definitely be hard balancing a 20-hour-per-week job with grad school, but to come out of school with no debt is priceless, so I highly recommend taking one of these positions if you can get your hands on one.

pros: I really like working for the university because they are very accomodating for students. I have held a few positions, and everyone I have worked with has been great.
cons: I don't have any major complaints. I think it really depends on what department of the university you are working for if it will be challenging or not to balance your responsibilities with schoolwork.

pros: Predictable pay increases and benefits. Many friendly people to work with.
cons: Way too bureaucratic!!!! The accounting and vending systems are the most kinked I have ever seen and need serious overhauling. The staff is great, they just have to deal with some systems that are far more arduous and convoluted than they need to be.

review_title: Good environment and lots of resources
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Lots of experts in all topics available.
Opportunities to learn through seminars, courses, etc.
Access to computing resources, testing facilities, and most other things you could need.
cons:
Very large, so it is possible to get ignored quite easily.
Postdoc pay is low (although this is more related to funding agencies such as NIH, and is pretty uniform across universities)
Having resouces scattered across multiple campuses.

pros: great schedule to work around and the staff were just great people in general. I would highly suggest this company to anybody, benefits were great
cons: some times HR comes down on their employees, especially male ones for false accusations, not very trusting of employees, Duluth campus was the worst

pros: You can get a lot of research experience, which is great if you want to do research for the rest of your life.
cons: The pay rates are terrible for Jr. Scientists and the cost of living raises at year end are almost nothing. If you have to pay for parking, it's a considerable amount to be taken out of your paycheck each month.

pros: Working as a TA provides the funding needed to pay my bills while obtaining a Masters degree. Relatively flexible schedule. Mostly good people willing to help out.
cons: Grading can take up a lot of time and ultimately keep you away from your research. Little collaboration between departments. Everyone looking out for themselves.

job_title: Bookstore Student Worker in Morris, MN
pros: Great co-workers that help train you in. They work around your schedule if you have classes during the day, and understand if you need to do homework.
cons: If you need a lot of hours, you can't get more than 10 or 12 if you are a student worker. This might be a good thing though since you have more time to concentrate on school.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Flexible hours, friendly staff, easy to make lifelong friends, simple work, and they let you do homework during slow times
cons: Not the kind of job for anyone who likes to talk. Since you are working in a library, they enforce absolute silence... but that's probably a given.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I loved working for the university of Minnesota for many reasons: Friendly, helpful people, great academic atmosphere, beautiful setting, Minnesota pride.
cons: The only part about working at the U was the parking and sometimes the traffic getting around campus. I've always hated the idea of having to pay for parking at work but I know that's the case at a lot of city employees

pros: If you are in the right department and with the right PI, you have a lot of freedom to grow your skills, etc for your next position. The benefits are good (healthcare), hours are flexible.
cons: Lots of politics, some academic apathy, difficult to advance. If you are in the wrong department/group leadership and training options may be limited. Pay is low.

pros: Excellent work environment and human resource department.  Also FANTASTIC HEALTH benefits!
cons: For an academic institution they are kind of stingy with the vacation times and the salaries aren't what you would make in the private sector

review_title: Great benefits and place to work
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth. Great benefit package. Lots of opportunities for additional training and professional development.
cons: Can feel like things sometimes move slow in a large university due to bureaucracy.

review_title: Working at the learning Abroad center
pros: Easy to work. Management is really nice. Flexible hours. As a student it gives me the required exposure and helped me gain office management skills.
cons: Tough to work with both work and school. However I don't see other problems working for the U of M. As I said having a nice supervisor who takes care of you help.

job_title: Senior Research Fellow in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits and work / home life balance.  Flexibility in how work is completed.  Challenging and creative environment with cutting edge technology.  Helping the citizens of the state improve their lives.
cons: Leadership can be absent and be a down side of the flexibility that is present with most jobs.  Government bureaucracy slows the machine and hinders change.

review_title: A good place to work. Great teams. University is supportive of employees and students.
pros: Great work culture. Inter disciplinary support is great. Plenty of learning opportunities and amenities. University supports the employees with tuition fees.
cons: Growth depends on your supervisor. No particular support on the employees career growth along with the groups growth. Knowledge workers are under rated and under paid like in many universities.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Graduate student at Chemical Engineering & Materials Science. Very nice department especially if one wants to get trained to become a professor. To move on to industry positions, the area of research matters a lot.
cons: Location of Minneapolis does not really help if you want to get into research positions in big companies. Opportunities in Texas, east coast, west coast are better.

review_title: A great place to work and learn with friendly, competent colleagues.
job_title: Business Development Professional I in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Excellent benefits
Tuition assistance - 100% for undergraduate program, 75% for graduate/professional programs
Work/life balance
cons:
Mixed opportunity for growth
Slowness of management to embrace change
Decentralization leads to inconsistent decision-making

pros: Very easy work if you use common sense. Relaxed work environment with flexible hours. Always something to do.
cons: Students are disrespectful to custodians. Mundane and repetitious work that can burnout a person if they don't have the right attitude.

pros: I have worked with and learned a lot from some of the best researchers in the world in my field.
cons: Minneapolis is a great city, with lots of green areas and cultural activities, but the cold weather can be a challenge.

review_title: Great experience as a student worker
pros: The University of Minnesota offers a wide array of jobs, including many student jobs. I worked as a parking attendant at the University which was a position under parking and transportation services. The University has a set minimum wage for student workers starting at $9.65/hr. The jobs are very lenient with class schedules.
cons: It is hard to trade shifts.

pros: Pay; job security if you are union
cons: Hiring freezes; lack of communication from senior management within colleges; no room for growth within the profession; too bureaucratic to be effective in implementing real change or strategy.

review_title: wonderful experience as a grad student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: great research culture, exceptionally smart people, cutting-edge research, hands-off attitude, brilliant camarederie, excellent pay, great facilities. Overall, a complete experience!
cons: because of the high ranking of the school, it gets very competitive when it comes to grades in classes. the long winter is also a big minus. but that is made up for by the beautiful winter.

review_title: Great school with great employment opportunities.
pros: Salary is good for college student, hours can easily fit with course schedule, some positions are low-key and you can do your homework there as well.
cons: Being a student and working even part-time can be challenging - make sure you have good time-management skills.

pros:
Friendly people work here (at least when I was working here) and high graduations chances.
Great location it is easy to reach.
cons:
Some people can be hard to teach but with smart tactics you can make them interested.
You have to pay for drink but this is no major issue.

pros: This is a very good place to work. Not as high a salary, but you get a pension and very good benefits.
cons: There really aren't many cons to working at the University of Minnesota. I guess it just depends on what department you work for. Management styles are very different department to department.

pros:
City is affordable 
University gives you great perks
Payment is average to the industry 
Great opportunity to develop new skills 
Excelent support from management
cons: Not enough human resource so you get a lot of responsibility and you participate in an on call rotation where you need to be able to respond for incidents

pros: If you like academia I would suggest this to those pursing a graduate degree.  You are able to learn as well as teach and guide students through review sessions.
cons: You never know if you are going to have the same job the following semester and the uncertainty makes it difficult to budget.

review_title: wonderful, a place of caring and learning and love
pros: awesome benefits, lots of cool opportunities for learning, nice co-workers, nice enviornment
cons: everything above is contingent on who you work for; that is, I worked in a lab and had a great experience but that's because the boss was very cool; things could be different otherwise.

job_title: Senior Office Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Vast amount of work, challenging, Working with patients to help them successfully get the treatment they needed.  Working with students.
cons: Negative environment.  Not much freedom to make decisions on your own.  Complacent in their mediocrity. Departments were pitted against one another.

pros: I love the environment. There is room for growth within the company. Competitive pay. Personal work space for medical assistants not just the management and physicians.
cons: High turnover rate for position.  Extra work load due to forms and refills.

job_title: Service Desk Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Flexible hours, great supervisor, ability to swap shifts and some of the best student-job pay.
cons: Many other college students dropping shifts on obvious party nights, in addition to late nights across campus in which you can nearly guarantee no patrons.

pros: The University of Minnesota is a large institution with many resources to research projects. These resources make it easy to conduct cutting edge research.
cons: The size of the University of Minnesota can make it difficult to find resources or connect with colleagues that may be able to help your research. There are events to try and correct this problem.

pros: Research opportunities are good here especially in Machine Learning and Distributed systems.
cons: Job Scene is one of the worst in the US for International Students. Lower ranked universities are far better than this. I would suggest to all international students who are choosing universities considering job opportunities to go to east or west coast.  Clear No for UMN.

pros: Decent flexibility, great benefits, nice to be in an environment of higher education, surrounded by amazing minds doing cool things
cons: There's almost no way to move up the ladder; rigid job categories prevent easily being promoted; To change positions or grow in any way you need to leave and come back (or...not come back).

review_title: Good place to work but inconsistent support for admin staff
job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good pay, good benefits, nice amenities, some nice people, exciting atmosphere, vibrant culture, centrally located
cons: Not enough support for lower level employees, too much support for directors, a little overly ambitious with respect to goals, a little impersonal.

pros: Working at the circulation desk allows you to interact with the law students and professors.
cons: Cleaning books to kill time was the worst part of working there. There was no chance for students to demonstrate their skills.

review_title: Great place to work, so much fun!
pros: Very fun place to work because it allows you to gain some of the skills you'll use in real life.
cons: Pay raises were put on hold during my tenure here at the University so i wasn't able to realize and monetary gain from my experience or length of time in the Department

pros: many brilliant people in different areas, a lot of interdisciplinary cooperation, a lot of good learning of new things. good place if you want to learn more things.
cons: overall it is good in all aspects, some concerns are a little bit low salary. some advisers is not always helping student out because they are very busy, it depends.

job_title: Building & Grounds Worker in Minneapolis, MN

Honestly, she her title and the words "Manager" and "Education," but she had never taught or even taken a class in education. She was an accomplished administrator, so for her, education meant writing reports about education instead of working with teacher to improve the quality of education.

pros: decent benefits, especially tuition coverage if you can juggle work, life and school .  in general, flexible with time off.

review_title: Fun work place with good mentoring and learning.
